Creating a main application with React that includes a sub-application built with Angular involves integrating two different frameworks in a single project. This kind of setup is commonly referred to as **Micro Frontends**. Below is a step-by-step guide on how to achieve this. ### Step 1: Set Up the React Application 1. **Create a new React application** using Create React App: ```bash npx create-react-app main-react-app cd main-react-app ``` 2. **Install the required dependencies** for loading Angular applications (optional: you might want to use single-spa for better micro-frontend architecture): ```bash npm install --save single-spa single-spa-react ``` ### Step 2: Create the Angular Application 1. In another directory, create the Angular application: ```bash ng new sub-angular-app cd sub-angular-app ``` 2. Generate a new module that you can load into your React application: ```bash ng generate module shell ng generate component shell/shell ``` 3. In the shell component, you can add some basic content to test: ```typescript // shell.component.ts import { Component } from '@angular/core'; @Component({ selector: 'app-shell', template: `<h2>Hello from Angular Shell!</h2>`, }) export class ShellComponent {} ``` ### Step 3: Build the Angular Application for Production 1. Build the Angular application. This step compiles the Angular project and outputs the built files. ```bash ng build --prod ``` 2. After building, you will find the build files in `dist/sub-angular-app`. ### Step 4: Serve Angular Application in React Now you need to load the Angular application from the React application. 1. In the `main-react-app/src` directory, create a folder named `angular-app`. 2. Copy the contents of `dist/sub-angular-app` into `main-react-app/src/angular-app`. 3. Create a component in the React application to load the Angular app. ```javascript // src/AngularLoader.js import React, { useEffect } from 'react'; const AngularLoader = () => { useEffect(() => { // Load Angular Script const script = document.createElement('script'); script.src = 'angular-app/main.js'; // Adjust path as needed script.onload = () => { // Logic to bootstrap Angular if necessary can go here }; document.body.appendChild(script); return () => { // Clean up script tag if needed document.body.removeChild(script); }; }, []); return <div id="angular-root"></div>; // Element where Angular will mount }; export default AngularLoader; ``` 4. In your main React component, import the AngularLoader and use it: ```javascript // src/App.js import React from 'react'; import AngularLoader from './AngularLoader'; function App() { return ( <div> <h1>Main React Application</h1> <AngularLoader /> </div> ); } export default App; ``` ### Step 5: Run the Combined Applications 1. Start your React application. ```bash npm start ``` 2. You should see the main React application with the Angular component loading inside of it. ### Important Considerations - **Communication Between Frameworks**: Consider how you'll handle communication between the React and Angular applications. For instance, using custom events or a shared state library could be beneficial. - **Single-SPA**: If you have complex requirements involving multiple micro-frontends, consider using libraries like [Single-SPA](https://single-spa.js.org/) that provide a structured way of integrating multiple frontend frameworks. - **Styling Conflicts**: Be mindful of possible CSS conflicts between the two frameworks. Consider using scoped CSS or CSS Modules to avoid clash. - **Routing**: If you need routing in your micro-frontend architecture, you may need to configure routing carefully in both React and Angular applications to prevent conflicts. This guide offers a starting point for integrating a React main application with an Angular sub-application. Let me know if you need further details on any specific part of the integration or any additional features!
thread_QMMp6wvgpHLlapQPNCBDux90
10:48 AM
When using Yarn to generate an Angular service, the command should still be executed with the `ng` prefix. However, since you might face issues with the `ng` command not being recognized if it's not in your PATH, it's important to ensure you are either using Yarn to execute the Angular CLI commands or that `ng` is globally accessible. Here‚Äôs how to generate an Angular service using Yarn: ### Step 1: Navigate to Your Angular Project Make sure you are in the root directory of your Angular project. You can navigate to your project folder using: ```bash cd path/to/your/angular/project ``` ### Step 2: Generate a Service You can generate a service using the Angular CLI with the following command: If `ng` is properly configured in your PATH: ```bash ng generate service service-name ``` Or the shorthand version: ```bash ng g service service-name ``` ### Step 3: Using Yarn to Run the Command (if ng is not recognized) If you are still facing issues with `ng` not being recognized directly, you can use Yarn to execute the Angular CLI command: ```bash yarn ng generate service service-name ``` or ```bash yarn ng g service service-name ``` ### Alternative Method (if ng is not available) If you still have issues using `ng`, you can also run the command using the script defined in your `package.json` (if you installed the Angular CLI locally): 1. **Add Angular CLI to Your Package** (if not installed): If you‚Äôre using a local version of Angular CLI, first ensure it's included in your `devDependencies`: ```bash yarn add @angular/cli --dev ``` 2. **Run Using Yarn Script**: After adding Angular CLI as a `devDependency`, you can then use Yarn to run it: ```bash yarn run ng generate service service-name ``` or ```bash yarn run ng g service service-name ``` ### Summary Commands 1. **Global Command**: ```bash ng g service service-name ``` 2. **Yarn Command (if ng not recognized)**: ```bash yarn ng g service service-name ``` 3. **Using Local Angular CLI**: ```bash yarn run ng g service service-name ``` ### Conclusion Choose the appropriate command based on your setup. If all commands execute successfully, a new service will be created within `src/app`, and you can further customize or implement logic in your service file. Be sure to replace `service-name` with your desired service name!

thread_XiBJd2Kw3ELi1ZEiNjkJTBK0
9:00 AM
4 days ago, Jan 23
The error message you posted indicates an issue related to Android build and installation. Here's a breakdown of what is happening and how to resolve it: ### Error Breakdown 1. **Failure Cause**: The installation of the app (task `:app:installDevRelease`) failed due to a signature mismatch. The existing version of the app (`com.techserv.dev`) on the device has a different signing certificate than the new version you are trying to install. - **Specific Error**: ```plaintext INSTALL_FAILED_UPDATE_INCOMPATIBLE: Existing package com.techserv.dev signatures do not match newer version; ignoring! ``` ### Resolution Steps To resolve this issue, you have a few options: 1. **Uninstall the Existing App**: - If you don‚Äôt need the existing version of the app, uninstall it from the device or emulator. You can do this manually or by running the following ADB command in your terminal: ```bash adb uninstall com.techserv.dev ``` 2. **Use the Same Signing Key**: - Ensure that you are using the same signing key that was used to sign the existing version of the application. If you have access to the keystore used previously, use it to sign your APK/AAB. 3. **Change Build Variants**: - If you are building an APK for development/testing purposes, consider changing the application ID or using a different signing configuration in your `build.gradle` file temporarily for debug builds to avoid conflicts. 4. **Recreate the Signing Key**: - If you no longer have access to the signing key used for the previous version, you may need to create a new key and increment the versionCode and versionName in your `build.gradle` before rebuilding and installing the app. However, note that this will not allow you to update the existing installation; it will lead to a new app installation. ### Additional Suggestions - Always keep a backup of your signing keys and keystores to avoid this situation. - For better debugging, run the build command with the `--stacktrace`, `--info`, or `--debug` options to provide more insight into what might be going wrong. ### Example Command To uninstall directly from the command line, you could run: ```bash adb uninstall com.techserv.dev ``` This will remove the existing version, allowing the installation of the new version with the mismatched signature. By following these steps, you should be able to fix the build failure and successfully install the updated application. Let me know if you need further assistance!

**‡∏ö‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏∂‡∏Å‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏ã‡πá‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á APK**: ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏ï ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏£‡∏ö‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏∂‡∏Å‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏ã‡πá‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ keystore Hello! üòä It sounds like you're encountering a "Service Unavailable" error (HTTP status 503) when trying to upload an audio file using Streamlit. This error typically indicates that the server is temporarily unable to handle the request, which can happen for several reasons. Here are some steps to diagnose and potentially resolve the issue: 1. **Check Server Status**: Ensure that your Streamlit server is running correctly. You may want to restart it to clear any temporary issues. 2. **Inspect Log Files**: Look at the logs from your Streamlit application for any specific error messages that could provide insights into what's going wrong. 3. **File Size Limits**: Check if the audio file you're trying to upload exceeds any size limits set in your Streamlit app. If so, you might need to increase the upload size limit. 4. **Network Issues**: Sometimes, network problems can cause such errors. Ensure that your internet connection is stable and that there are no firewall restrictions blocking the upload. 5. **Resource Limits**: If you're running your Streamlit app on a cloud service (like Heroku, AWS, etc.), ensure that you have enough resources allocated (CPU, memory, etc.) to handle the upload. 6. **Deploy Environment Check**: If you're deploying Streamlit via Docker or another container solution, verify that the environment is set up correctly and that all necessary dependencies are installed. 7. **Update Streamlit**: Ensure you're using the latest version of Streamlit, as bugs and issues can be fixed in newer releases. Use `pip install --upgrade streamlit` to update. 8. **Check File Type**: Confirm that the audio file is in a supported format, as some applications might reject unsupported file types. 9. **Error Handling in Code**: If you have custom code to handle file uploads, ensure that you are implementing appropriate error handling. You might want to catch exceptions and return user-friendly error messages. If you've gone through these steps and are still encountering the issue, feel free to share some code snippets or more context about your environment, and I'll be glad to help further! üéâ

‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡πÄ‡∏´‡πá‡∏ô log ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡πÑ‡∏ß‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô `veryIntensiveTask` ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏™‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏ï‡∏∏‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏•‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ß‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡πÅ‡∏Å‡πâ‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤: ### 1. ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ `BackgroundService` ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏á ‡πÜ ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≠‡∏¢ ‡πÜ ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ `BackgroundService` ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ log ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÉ‡∏ô `BackgroundService.start` ‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `veryIntensiveTask`: ```javascript console.log('Attempting to start BackgroundService...'); await BackgroundService.start(veryIntensiveTask, options); console.log('Started BackgroundService successfully!'); ``` ### 2. ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `callTaskByQueue()` ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà `callTaskByQueue()` ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏ú‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏û‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏î‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏î‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏ô‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ ‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏õ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏° log ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô: ```javascript const callTaskByQueue = async () => { console.log('callTaskByQueue is called'); // function logic... }; ``` ### 3. ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Promise ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏á ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô `veryIntensiveTask`, ‡∏Ç‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î Promise ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ async/await ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô: ```javascript const veryIntensiveTask = async () => { console.log('Starting veryIntensiveTask...'); while (BackgroundService.isRunning()) { console.log('Running task in veryIntensiveTask...'); await callTaskByQueue(); await sleep(delay); console.log('Completed a task in veryIntensiveTask...'); } }; ``` ### 4. ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö permission ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÅ‡∏≠‡∏õ‡∏û‡∏•‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ permission ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏°‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ô background ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ç‡∏≠ permission ‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏¥‡∏î‡πÅ‡∏≠‡∏õ‡πÉ‡∏ô background ‡πÉ‡∏ô `AndroidManifest.xml` ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÇ‡∏ü‡∏£‡πÇ‡∏°‡∏ä‡∏±‡πà‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö background task ### 5. ‡∏ó‡∏î‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÉ‡∏ô Device ‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏á ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `BackgroundService` ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏î‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÉ‡∏ô Emulator. ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏î‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏∏‡∏õ‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏ì‡πå‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏á ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏ô Emulator ‡∏•‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô settings ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏° resource limit ‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏™‡∏π‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô ### 6. ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö error ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ manager service ‡∏Ñ‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πá‡∏Ñ console log ‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö error ‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô ‡πÜ ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏è‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÅ‡∏™‡∏î‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô console log ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö logcat ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Android Studio ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏ß‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏ö‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà ‡πÇ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏î‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö error ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏™‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÅ‡∏ß‡∏î‡∏•‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏â‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏¥‡πà‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô!

If your app crashes immediately after reaching the log statement `console.log('try start background service');` on Android 14, there could be several underlying issues causing this behavior. Here are some steps to troubleshoot and resolve the problem: ### 1. **Check Permissions** Ensure that the app has the necessary permissions to start background services. In Android 14, certain permissions related to background processing and foreground services may have additional requirements. Make sure you've declared the permission in your `AndroidManifest.xml`: ```xml <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.FOREGROUND_SERVICE"/> ``` ### 2. **Enable Foreground Service Type** Starting from Android 9 (API level 28), you must specify the type of foreground service you are using. If your service involves data syncing, use the following configuration in `AndroidManifest.xml`: ```xml <service android:name=".YourBackgroundService" android:foregroundServiceType="dataSync" /> ``` Make sure to replace `.YourBackgroundService` with the correct class name where your background task logic resides. ### 3. **Inspect Logcat for Errors** Use Android's Logcat to check for any crash logs or error messages that occur when you try to start the background service. This will give you insights into what went wrong. You can filter the logs by your app's package name. Open the terminal and run: ```bash adb logcat | grep your.package.name ``` ### 4. **Check for Exceptions in Your Task** Ensure that the function `callTaskByQueue()` and other related functions do not throw any uncaught exceptions. Wrap the code in a `try-catch` block to handle any potential errors: ```javascript const veryIntensiveTask = async () => { console.log('on veryIntensiveTask'); try { while (BackgroundService.isRunning()) { console.log('>>>>>>run taskWorker'); await callTaskByQueue(); await sleep(delay); } } catch (error) { console.error('Error in veryIntensiveTask:', error); } }; ``` ### 5. **Test with a Simplified Task** Temporarily replace `callTaskByQueue()` with a simple log statement to verify whether the crash is specifically related to the task function itself: ```javascript const veryIntensiveTask = async () => { console.log('on veryIntensiveTask'); while (BackgroundService.isRunning()) { console.log('Background service is running'); await sleep(5000); // Sleep for 5 seconds } }; ``` ### 6. **Update Libraries** Make sure that you are using the latest versions of all relevant libraries, including `react-native-background-actions`. Sometimes compatibility issues arise with newer versions of React Native or Android, and library updates can contain important fixes. ```bash npm update react-native-background-actions ``` ### 7. **Check for Other Crash Sources** If you're seeing your app crash even before it starts the background service, other parts of the app (like your login logic) might be causing the issue. Make sure to check and isolate any other components that could be problematic. ### 8. **Test on a Physical Device** In some cases, background task behavior is different on emulators compared to physical devices. Make sure you test on an actual device running Android 14. ### Summary To resolve the crash issue when starting `BackgroundService`, ensure all permissions are correctly set, that your task functions are properly handled with error checking, and inspect the logs for any relevant messages. Simplifying the task temporarily can help identify if the problem lies within the background task logic itself. Lastly, always ensure you're on the latest library versions compatible with your current React Native setup.

To write unit tests for the specified segment of code, you can use a testing framework such as NUnit, xUnit, or MSTest in C#. The idea is to create test cases that would cover both scenarios: when `isCanceled` is `true` and when it is `false`. Here's a step-by-step approach to create the unit tests for this line of code. ### 1. Define the Dependencies You'll need dependencies such as a mock of the repository or any service used, and you may need to mock the methods like `MapTransactionBySalesOrder`. Consider using a mocking framework like Moq. ### 2. Create the Test Class and Methods Below is an example of how to structure your test class using xUnit and Moq. ```csharp using System; using System.Collections.Generic; using Moq; using Xunit; public class VehicleStockTests { [Fact] public void Test_AddTransaction_WhenIsCanceledIsTrue() { // Arrange var vehicleStockProduct = new VehicleStockProduct { Transactions = new List<VehicleStockEntity.Transaction>() }; var product = new SalesOrderProduct { SaleUnit = new SaleUnit { PriceIncludeVat = 100 }, BaseUnit = new BaseUnit { PriceIncludeVat = 80 } }; var baseUnitQuantity = 5; bool isCanceled = true; string salesOrderNo = "SO123"; var mockTransaction = new VehicleStockEntity.Transaction { // Set up properties as needed }; var mockedMapper = new Mock<Mapper>(); mockedMapper.Setup(m => m.MapTransactionBySalesOrder(It.IsAny<int>(), It.IsAny<decimal>(), It.IsAny<decimal>(), TransactionType.SalesCancelations, salesOrderNo)) .Returns(mockedTransaction); // Act if (isCanceled) { vehicleStockProduct.Transactions.Add(mockedMapper.Object.MapTransactionBySalesOrder( baseUnitQuantity, product.SaleUnit.PriceIncludeVat, product.BaseUnit.PriceIncludeVat, TransactionType.SalesCancelations, salesOrderNo)); } // Assert Assert.Single(vehicleStockProduct.Transactions); Assert.Equal(TransactionType.SalesCancelations, vehicleStockProduct.Transactions[0].TransactionType); } [Fact] public void Test_AddTransaction_WhenIsCanceledIsFalse() { // Arrange - Similar setup as above with isCanceled set to false var vehicleStockProduct = new VehicleStockProduct { Transactions = new List<VehicleStockEntity.Transaction>() }; var product = new SalesOrderProduct { SaleUnit = new SaleUnit { PriceIncludeVat = 100 }, BaseUnit = new BaseUnit { PriceIncludeVat = 80 } }; var baseUnitQuantity = 5; bool isCanceled = false; string salesOrderNo = "SO123"; var mockTransaction = new VehicleStockEntity.Transaction { // Set up properties as needed }; var mockedMapper = new Mock<Mapper>(); mockedMapper.Setup(m => m.MapTransactionBySalesOrder(It.IsAny<int>(), It.IsAny<decimal>(), It.IsAny<decimal>(), TransactionType.Sales, salesOrderNo)) .Returns(mockedTransaction); // Act vehicleStockProduct.Transactions.Add(mockedMapper.Object.MapTransactionBySalesOrder( baseUnitQuantity, product.SaleUnit.PriceIncludeVat, product.BaseUnit.PriceIncludeVat, TransactionType.Sales, salesOrderNo)); // Assert Assert.Single(vehicleStockProduct.Transactions); Assert.Equal(TransactionType.Sales, vehicleStockProduct.Transactions[0].TransactionType); } } public class VehicleStockProduct { public List<VehicleStockEntity.Transaction> Transactions { get; set; } = new List<VehicleStockEntity.Transaction>(); } public class SalesOrderProduct { public SaleUnit SaleUnit { get; set; } public BaseUnit BaseUnit { get; set; } } public class SaleUnit { public decimal PriceIncludeVat { get; set; } } public class BaseUnit { public decimal PriceIncludeVat { get; set; } } public class VehicleStockEntity { public class Transaction { public TransactionType TransactionType { get; set; } // Other properties } } public enum TransactionType { Sales, SalesCancelations } ``` ### Explanation 1. **Mocks**: We are using Moq to create a mock of the `MapTransactionBySalesOrder` method. 2. **Test Cases**: - `Test_AddTransaction_WhenIsCanceledIsTrue`: Tests the scenario when `isCanceled` is `true`. - `Test_AddTransaction_WhenIsCanceledIsFalse`: Tests the scenario when `isCanceled` is `false`. 3. **Assertions**: Each test checks that the transaction has been added to the list and confirms the type of transaction added. ### Conclusion This setup should cover the functionality you wanted to unit test. Adjust the properties of the `mockTransaction` as per your actual implementation. Also, if `MapTransactionBySalesOrder` is a member of a specific class, you should create a mock of that class accordingly.

It seems that the `isShowCancel()` method is being called due to Angular's change detection, which may occur when the component is rendered. The way you've structured your component means that if your template references `isShowCancel()` in the HTML, Angular will call it during its change detection cycle, even before the `ngOnInit()` lifecycle hook completes. To ensure that your initial logic is completed in `ngOnInit()` before checking the visibility of the cancel option, you can follow these strategies: ### Solution 1: Use a Boolean Flag You can introduce a boolean flag to determine whether the `ngOnInit()` lifecycle has completed its execution before allowing `isShowCancel()` to return a value. Here‚Äôs how you can implement this: ```typescript @Component({ // component metadata }) export class PaymentSummariesPageComponent implements OnInit { // Existing properties... isInitComplete: boolean = false; // Add a new flag async ngOnInit(): Promise<void> { this.documentNo = await this.routeService.getValueFromParams(QueryParamsKey.DocumentNo, this.route); this.getSalesSummary(this.documentNo); this.isShowBack(this.router.url); this.isInitComplete = true; // Set the flag to true to indicate init completion } isShowCancel(): boolean { // Return false if initialization is not complete if (!this.isInitComplete) return false; const dateToday = new Date(); this.salesSummary.isCanceled = false; this.documentDate = new Date(this.salesSummary.documentDate); if (!this.salesSummary.isCanceled && this.documentDate.toDateString() === dateToday.toDateString()) { return true; } else { return false; } }; } ``` ### Solution 2: Conditional Rendering in Template If you're using `isShowCancel()` directly in your template, you can conditionally render parts of the template based on the component's initialization completion. For instance: ```html <div *ngIf="isInitComplete"> <button *ngIf="isShowCancel()">Cancel</button> <!-- Other template code --> </div> ``` ### Explanation 1. **Boolean Flag**: By maintaining an `isInitComplete` boolean flag, you tell Angular not to consider the results of `isShowCancel()` until `ngOnInit()` has finished executing. 2. **Conditional Rendering**: By incorporating the flag in your template, you ensure that the cancel button only renders once the initialization phase is fully completed, avoiding premature calls. These approaches should help in controlling the lifecycle so that your initial setup in `ngOnInit()` gets completed before `isShowCancel()` is evaluated. Choose the approach that best fits your application logic and UI design.

In simple terms, you are trying to use something that hasn't been initialized or that no instance exists. 2. **Assertion Failure**: - The test was expecting to receive a `System.Exception` to be thrown, suggesting that it anticipated an error related to product lookup failure (since the test is named `UpdateStockBySalesOrderProduct_ItShouldThrowExceptionWhenProductNotFound`). You might want it to also check for `NullReferenceException` if that's the logical outcome when a product isn't found. 4. **Example of Debugging**: - Here‚Äôs a pseudocode approach to demonstrate how null-checking can be implemented: ```csharp if (someObject == null) { throw new Exception("Expected object not found for provided products."); } // Proceed with further processing. ``` ### Conclusion: The `NullReferenceException` indicates that there‚Äôs an uninitialized object being used in your `UpdateStockBySalesOrderProduct` method. The error message "Cannot implicitly convert type 'string' to 'bool'" indicates that the method `_salesOrderClient.Patch<object, string>()` is returning a string, but your `Cancel` method is expected to return a boolean (`bool`). In order to fix this issue, you need to either convert the string result to a boolean value or change the return type of your `Cancel` method if it's intended to return a string instead. Here are a couple of suggestions: ### Option 1: Return a Boolean If the API call indicates cancellation success with a specific string (e.g., "Success" or similar), you can adjust the code to return true or false based on that response. Here‚Äôs how you could modify your method: ```csharp public async Task<bool> Cancel(string salesOrderNo) { return await ApmHelper.ExecuteWithSpanAsync("SalesOrder.Cancel", LogSpanType.service.ToString(), async () => { var result = await _salesOrderClient.Patch<object, string>( null, $"{_urlService.Value.SalesOrder}/sales-orders/{salesOrderNo}/cancel"); // Example: Assume that "Success" indicates a successful cancellation return result == "Success"; }); } ``` ### Option 2: Change Return Type to String If your intention is to retrieve a string response instead of a boolean, modify the return type of your `Cancel` method: ```csharp public async Task<string> Cancel(string salesOrderNo) { return await ApmHelper.ExecuteWithSpanAsync("SalesOrder.Cancel", LogSpanType.service.ToString(), async () => { return await _salesOrderClient.Patch<object, string>( null, $"{_urlService.Value.SalesOrder}/sales-orders/{salesOrderNo}/cancel"); }); } ``` ### Conclusion Choose the option that best fits your business logic and expected behavior. If you expect a boolean response from the cancellation API, then Option 1 is appropriate. If you need the string for further processing or logging, go with Option 2. Make sure to always handle potential exceptions and ensure your API client behaves as expected, especially in cases of unexpected responses or errors.

Your current implementation for the `Cancel` method is almost correct, but there are a few considerations to ensure it's working properly. ### Suggested Code Improvement Here's an updated version of your `Cancel` method code: ```csharp public async Task<bool> Cancel(string salesOrderNo) { return await ApmHelper.ExecuteWithSpanAsync("SalesOrder.Cancel", LogSpanType.service.ToString(), async () => { // Call the Patch method with null as the body and check for success var result = await _salesOrderClient.Patch<object, string>( null, $"{_urlService.Value.SalesOrder}/sales-orders/{salesOrderNo}/cancel"); // Assuming the result is a string message; adapt as needed return !string.IsNullOrEmpty(result) && result.Equals("success", StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase); }); } ``` ### Key Changes and Considerations 1. **Return Value Handling**: - After the `Patch` call, I‚Äôm checking the result. Typically, you would want to evaluate whether the result indicates a successful cancellation. If the API returns a specific success message or status code, handle that accordingly. 2. **Generic Types**: - I maintained the `_salesOrderClient.Patch<object, string>(...)` syntax, assuming that your `Patch` method is designed to return a string response while taking an object as the body. Ensure that this aligns with the actual API you're interfacing with. 3. **Error Handling**: - Consider adding additional error handling within the inner function. Wrapping your call in a try-catch block may help you log any exceptions that occur during the API call. ### Example of Error Handling (Optional) You might want to add error handling like this: ```csharp public async Task<bool> Cancel(string salesOrderNo) { return await ApmHelper.ExecuteWithSpanAsync("SalesOrder.Cancel", LogSpanType.service.ToString(), async () => { try { var result = await _salesOrderClient.Patch<object, string>( null, $"{_urlService.Value.SalesOrder}/sales-orders/{salesOrderNo}/cancel"); return !string.IsNullOrEmpty(result) && result.Equals("success", StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase); } catch (Exception ex) { // Log the exception as needed // e.g., Logger.LogError(ex, "Failed to cancel sales order {SalesOrderNo}", salesOrderNo); return false; // Ensure that we return false on failure } }); } ``` ### Testing Make sure to test this function by: - Calling it with valid `salesOrderNo` values. - Handling any edge cases such as invalid order numbers or connection issues to see if the error handling behaves as expected. This approach ensures that your method remains robust and provides clear feedback on its operation.

2:18 PM
When considering replacing `console.log` statements with a formal logging framework, there are several popular options that can provide enhanced functionality, flexibility, and configurability for logging in JavaScript (particularly in Node.js applications): 1. **Winston** - **Description:** A versatile logging library that supports multiple transports (e.g., console, files, databases) and allows for log levels, custom formatting, and more. - **Usage:** ```javascript import winston from 'winston'; const logger = winston.createLogger({ level: 'info', format: winston.format.json(), transports: [ new winston.transports.Console(), new winston.transports.File({ filename: 'combined.log' }), ], }); // Example usage logger.info('This is an info message'); logger.error('This is an error message'); ``` 2. **Pino** - **Description:** A fast logger with a very small footprint. It is designed to be low overhead and can be integrated easily into applications. - **Usage:** ```javascript import pino from 'pino'; const logger = pino({ level: 'info', transport: { target: 'pino-pretty', // For pretty printing logs to console }, }); // Example usage logger.info('This is an info message'); logger.error('This is an error message'); ``` 3. **Bunyan** - **Description:** A simple and fast JSON logging library that is great for logging in production applications. Allows for easy integration with various logging systems. - **Usage:** ```javascript import bunyan from 'bunyan'; const logger = bunyan.createLogger({ name: 'myapp' }); // Example usage logger.info('This is an info message'); logger.error('This is an error message'); ``` 4. **Log4js** - **Description:** A logging library that is inspired by the Log4j framework in Java. It allows configuration through JSON or XML files and includes various appenders. - **Usage:** ```javascript import log4js from 'log4js'; log4js.configure({ appenders: { out: { type: 'console' }, file: { type: 'file', filename: 'logs/app.log' } }, categories: { default: { appenders: ['out', 'file'], level: 'info' } }, }); const logger = log4js.getLogger(); // Example usage logger.info('This is an info message'); logger.error('This is an error message'); ``` ### Summary Choosing the right logging framework depends on your specific requirements, such as performance, ease of use, features, and integration. **Winston** and **Pino** are widely popular for their flexibility and performance. **Bunyan** is also a solid choice if you prefer structured logging in JSON format. It‚Äôs advisable to evaluate each option and select the one that best fits your project needs.

The error message you are encountering indicates that the C# compiler cannot infer the type arguments for the `Patch` method from the parameters you've provided. Specifically, when calling `Patch`, you're passing `null` as the first argument, which doesn't allow the compiler to determine the type of `T`. To resolve this issue, you need to explicitly specify the type arguments when calling the `Patch` method. Since you're passing `null`, you should define what type `T` you expect it to be. ### Updated Code Snippet Here‚Äôs how to modify your `Cancel` method to specify the type arguments: ```csharp public async Task<bool> Cancel(string salesOrderNo) { return await ApmHelper.ExecuteWithSpanAsync("SalesOrder.Cancel", LogSpanType.service.ToString(), async () => { // Specify the type arguments explicitly, e.g., if T is `object` and U is `bool` return await _salesOrderClient.Patch<object, bool>( null, $"{_urlService.Value.SalesOrder}/sales-orders/{salesOrderNo}/cancel"); }); } ``` ### Explanation: - **Explicit Type Arguments**: By specifying the types explicitly (in this case, I used `object` for `T` and `bool` for `U`), you inform the compiler what generic types it should use, allowing it to resolve the call. - **Adjust Types as Necessary**: Replace `object` and `bool` with the appropriate types you expect for the `Patch` method. For example, if your API returns some specific type as a result of the `Patch`, replace `bool` with that type. ### Alternative Hash If you have a specific type that `T` should be, you can define that in place of `object`. Here is a conceptual example: ```csharp // Assuming `CancelRequest` is the request type and `CancelResponse` is the response type. return await _salesOrderClient.Patch<CancelRequest, CancelResponse>( null, $"{_urlService.Value.SalesOrder}/sales-orders/{salesOrderNo}/cancel"); ``` ### Conclusion Specify the appropriate types based on what your API expects and returns. This will allow the C# compiler to resolve the generic method properly and eliminate the error. If you have specific types that should be used, feel free to provide them, and I can assist you with that.

thread_xAa82Z2tbU5M1BFNoaXsdOoI
9:34 AM
To remove a folder in the terminal, you can use the `rm` command followed by the `-r` (recursive) option, which allows you to delete a directory and its contents. Here‚Äôs the basic syntax: ```bash rm -r path/to/directory ``` ### Example If you have a folder named `my_folder` that you want to remove, you would use: ```bash rm -r my_folder ``` ### Important Notes: - **Use with caution**: The `rm -r` command permanently deletes the folder along with all its files and subdirectories. There is no way to recover them after this command is executed. - **To prompt before deletion**: You can add the `-i` option to prompt for confirmation before each file or folder is deleted: ```bash rm -ri path/to/directory ``` - **Force deletion**: If you want to bypass confirmation prompts, you can use the `-f` option: ```bash rm -rf path/to/directory ``` Make sure to double-check the folder path you are deleting to avoid accidental data loss.

To decode a Base64-encoded PDF string created in .NET using `Convert.ToBase64String()`, extract text while preserving its formatting in Kotlin, and prepare it for printing, follow these steps: 1. **Decode the Base64 string into a `ByteArray`**. 2. **Use a library like Apache PDFBox** to extract text from the PDF while trying to keep the formatting. 3. **Format the extracted text as needed for printing**. ### Complete Implementation ### Step 1: Add PDFBox Dependency Ensure you have the following dependency in your `build.gradle` file to use PDFBox: ```groovy dependencies { implementation 'org.apache.pdfbox:pdfbox:2.0.24' // Check for the latest version } ``` ### Step 2: Decode the Base64 String You'll need a method to decode the Base64 string into a byte array: ```kotlin import java.util.Base64 fun decodeBase64ToByteArray(base64String: String): ByteArray? { return try { Base64.getDecoder().decode(base64String) } catch (e: IllegalArgumentException) { println("Failed to decode Base64 string: ${e.message}") null } } ``` ### Step 3: Extract Formatted Text from PDF Now, create a method to extract text from the PDF using PDFBox. This example will try to preserve the text layout: ```kotlin import org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDDocument import org.apache.pdfbox.text.PDFTextStripper import java.io.ByteArrayInputStream import java.io.IOException fun extractFormattedTextFromPdf(pdfBytes: ByteArray): String { return try { // Load the PDF from the byte array PDDocument.load(ByteArrayInputStream(pdfBytes)).use { document -> val pdfStripper = PDFTextStripper() pdfStripper.setSortByPosition(true) // Maintains the layout for better formatting pdfStripper.getText(document) // Get the formatted text } } catch (e: IOException) { println("Failed to extract text from PDF: ${e.message}") "" } } ``` ### Step 4: Main Function to Tie Everything Together Finally, create a main function that ties all steps together, accepting a Base64-encoded PDF string, decoding it, extracting the text, and preparing it for printing. ```kotlin fun main() { // Sample Base64 encoded PDF string (replace with your actual Base64 string) val base64PDF = "JVBERi0xLjQKJcfs..." // Replace with your actual Base64 encoded PDF // Step 1: Decode Base64 String to ByteArray val pdfBytes: ByteArray? = decodeBase64ToByteArray(base64PDF) // Step 2: Check if decoding was successful if (pdfBytes != null) { // Step 3: Extract formatted text from the PDF val extractedText = extractFormattedTextFromPdf(pdfBytes) // Print the extracted text or prepare it for printing println("Extracted Formatted Text: \n$extractedText") // Here you could call a print function if you are printing the extracted text // printText(extractedText) // Uncomment when implementing print functionality } else { println("Failed to decode the PDF.") } } ``` ### Notes on Formatting for Printing 1. **Text Layout**: The method `setSortByPosition(true)` in `PDFTextStripper` helps preserve the reading order of text in the PDF. However, depending on how the PDF is created, formatting (like bullet points, columns, etc.) might not always be perfectly preserved. 2. **Preparing for Print**: If you need to modify the text format further (i.e., adding new lines, cleaning spaces, etc.), you can do that in the string returned from `extractedText`. 3. **Printing Functionality**: To actually send the extracted text to a printer, you will need an additional implementation based on the printing method you are using in Kotlin (whether it be sending to a physical printer, generating a new document, etc.). Here is a placeholder for a simple print function you could implement: ```kotlin fun printText(text: String) { // Implement your printing logic here // Example: Sending text to a printer connected via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi println("Printing text: \n$text") } ``` ### Conclusion By following these steps, you can effectively decode a Base64-encoded PDF string, extract its text while preserving formatting as much as possible, and prepare it for printing in Kotlin. If you have further questions or specific requirements, feel free to ask!

The error message `Unresolved reference: Charset` indicates that there is still an issue with referencing the `Charset` class. This can happen if you do not have the appropriate import statement or if the Kotlin standard library is not correctly referenced in your project. ### Steps to Resolve Unresolved Reference Errors 1. **Import Charset**: Make sure you have the import statement for `Charset` at the top of your `BluetoothPrinterModule.kt` file. Here‚Äôs the correct import statement to use: ```kotlin import java.nio.charset.Charset ``` 2. **Verify Project Setup**: Ensure that your project has access to the Java standard library. The `java.nio.charset.Charset` class is part of the Java platform, and it should be available in a correctly configured Kotlin environment. There isn‚Äôt usually a specific dependency required for this, but double-check your project setup. 3. **Check Your Gradle Files**: Also, verify that your `build.gradle` files are correctly set up and that you are using a version of Kotlin that is compatible with the Android Gradle Plugin. Your `android/app/build.gradle` should contain the following in the `dependencies` section: ```groovy implementation "org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-stdlib-jdk7:$kotlin_version" ``` Make sure you define `kotlin_version` earlier in the file, or set it in your project-level `build.gradle`, such as: ```groovy ext.kotlin_version = '1.5.21' // or your project's Kotlin version ``` 4. **Clean and Rebuild**: After ensuring the correct import and verifying the dependencies, clean and rebuild your project to ensure everything is properly set up: ```bash ./gradlew clean ./gradlew app:installDebug ``` 5. **Example `BluetoothPrinterModule.kt` File**: Here‚Äôs an illustrative example of what your `BluetoothPrinterModule.kt` might look like after including the necessary import: ```kotlin package com.downloadsubapps import java.io.IOException import java.nio.charset.Charset // Ensure this import is present import com.facebook.react.bridge.ReactMethod import com.facebook.react.bridge.Promise class BluetoothPrinterModule { @ReactMethod fun printText(text: String, promise: Promise) { try { if (outputStream != null) { // Convert Thai text to byte array using specific charset val textBytes = text.toByteArray(Charset.forName("Windows-874")) // Ensure Charset is used correctly outputStream?.write(textBytes) // Send completion command val newLineCommand = byteArrayOf(0x0A) // Line feed (LF) outputStream?.write(newLineCommand) // Flush the stream to send data outputStream?.flush() // Resolve promise if successful promise.resolve("Printed successfully") } else { promise.reject("NOT_CONNECTED", "Printer is not connected") } } catch (e: IOException) { e.printStackTrace() promise.reject("PRINT_FAILED", "Failed to print: ${e.message}") } } } ``` ### Summary By ensuring the correct import statement for the `Charset` class and verifying your project dependencies, the unresolved reference error should be resolved. If the issues persist, please share your `build.gradle` configuration and any additional information that may help diagnose the problem.

The error message you're experiencing indicates multiple issues during the build process of your React Native project. Let's break it down step by step and address the concerns: ### Key Issues Identified: 1. **SDK Version Compatibility**: - The warning about SDK XML versions suggests there may be a version mismatch between your Android Studio and command-line tools. 2. **Deprecated API Usage**: - Numerous modules are showing messages related to deprecated APIs. Although this may not directly cause the build to fail, it is advisable to refactor this code to prevent future issues. 3. **Symbol Not Found Errors**: - These errors are critical as they indicate that certain classes and interfaces (like `UIBlockViewResolver`, `UIBlock`) used in the `react-native-view-shot` module cannot be resolved during compilation. ### Recommended Solutions: 1. **Upgrade SDK Tools**: - Ensure that your Android SDK and build tools are up to date: - Open Android Studio. - Navigate to `SDK Manager` and check for updates for both SDK Tools and SDK Platforms. - Sync your project's Gradle files once updated. 2. **Check Dependencies**: - Ensure that your `react-native-view-shot` and other dependencies are compatible with your version of React Native: - Check the official [react-native-view-shot GitHub page](https://github.com/react-native-view-shot/react-native-view-shot) for compatibility notes and the recommended version for your React Native version. - Consider upgrading or downgrading the `react-native-view-shot` to match the dependencies. 3. **Run with Warnings**: - You can set your build to show warnings which may help you catch additional issues: ```bash cd android ./gradlew assembleDebug -Xlint:deprecation -Xlint:unchecked ``` 4. **Clear Gradle Cache**: - Sometimes, build artifacts may cause issues. Try clearing the cache: ```bash cd android ./gradlew clean ``` 5. **Reinstall Node Modules**: - Occasionally, reinstalling all npm packages can solve build issues: ```bash rm -rf node_modules npm install ``` 6. **Upgrade React Native**: - If possible, consider upgrading your React Native version. Newer versions may offer better support for the latest Android dependencies. ### Follow-Up: After making these changes, attempt to rebuild your Android app. If you continue experiencing issues, please provide the updated error messages for further assistance!

It looks like you're trying to write a Kotlin function that decodes a Base64 string into regular text. Below is a corrected implementation of your `base64ToText` function using Kotlin: ```kotlin import android.util.Base64 @ReactMethod fun base64ToText(base64: String): String { val bytes = Base64.decode(base64, Base64.DEFAULT) return String(bytes, Charsets.UTF_8) } ``` ### Explanation: - **Import Statement**: You need to import the `Base64` class from `android.util`. - **Base64 Decoding**: The `Base64.decode()` method decodes the Base64 string into bytes. - **Convert to String**: You then convert the bytes back to a string using the `String` constructor and specify the UTF-8 character set. This function will return the decoded text from the provided Base64 string. Make sure to handle any potential exceptions that may occur during the decoding process if you are uncertain about the input. If you need help with testing or further modifications, feel free to ask!

thread_wSwdFNJfIxxtTEnq2FBv2r1d
1:39 PM
The error message you encountered indicates a conflict in your ASP.NET Core application that uses Swagger for API documentation. Specifically, it states that there are two actions in your `BillingsController` that share the same HTTP method and path combination, which Swagger (using OpenAPI 3.0) does not allow. ### Problem Analysis: Your `BillingsController` has two methods defined like so: - `GetReceiptDocument` ‚Äî likely defined as a `GET` endpoint at the route `v1/billings`. - `GetReceiptDocumentText` ‚Äî also defined as a `GET` endpoint at the same route `v1/billings`. Since both methods respond to the same route with the same HTTP method, this results in a conflict. ### Solutions to Resolve the Conflict: 1. **Change the Route**: Modify one of the method routes so that they have unique paths. This could involve modifying the route attributes on the methods. For example: ```csharp [HttpGet("/v1/billings/receipt-document")] public IActionResult GetReceiptDocument() { // Implementation } [HttpGet("/v1/billings/receipt-document-text")] public IActionResult GetReceiptDocumentText() { // Implementation } ``` 2. **Use Different HTTP Methods**: If semantically appropriate for your application, you could change one of the methods to use a different HTTP method. For instance, if `GetReceiptDocumentText` should be a `POST`, you would adjust accordingly. 3. **Use Route Parameters**: If both operations are related, you could incorporate route parameters to differentiate them: ```csharp [HttpGet("/v1/billings/{id}/document")] public IActionResult GetReceiptDocument(int id) { // Implementation } [HttpGet("/v1/billings/{id}/document-text")] public IActionResult GetReceiptDocumentText(int id) { // Implementation } ``` 4. **Use Action Name Routing**: If you need to keep the routes the same for some reason within a Swagger context, you can use the `ActionName` attribute to differentiate the actions. However, this is less common and may not be the best RESTful practice. ```csharp [HttpGet("/v1/billings")] [ActionName("GetReceiptDocument")] public IActionResult GetReceiptDocument() { // Implementation } [HttpGet("/v1/billings")] [ActionName("GetReceiptDocumentText")] public IActionResult GetReceiptDocumentText() { // Implementation } ``` ### Verify Changes: After you make one of these changes, rebuild your project and test your API. This should resolve the conflict being reported by Swagger. ### Configuring Swagger to Ignore Conflicts: If you prefer to keep the same method and path, you can also configure Swagger to ignore conflicts by implementing a `ConflictingActionsResolver`. Here's a basic implementation guide: 1. Install the `Swashbuckle.AspNetCore` package if you haven't already. 2. In your `Startup.cs`, configure Swagger with a conflict resolver: ```csharp services.AddSwaggerGen(options => { options.ResolveConflictingActions(apiDescriptions => apiDescriptions.First()); // Keep the first description }); ``` While this change allows Swagger to document overlapping routes, it's generally better to use unique identifiers whenever possible to maintain clear API documentation. Let me know if you need further assistance or a specific implementation detail!

‡πÄ‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà ‡πÜ ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÅ‡∏Å‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤: ### ‡πÅ‡∏Å‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ô‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤ 1. **‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á React Native**: ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏•‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏´‡∏°‡∏î‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏£‡πà‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö React Native ‡πÄ‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏•‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏µ‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß 2. **‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï `react-native-view-shot`**: ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `react-native-view-shot` ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏•‡πà‡∏≤‡∏™‡∏∏‡∏î‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö React Native: ```bash npm install --save react-native-view-shot@latest ``` 3. **‡∏õ‡∏¥‡∏î‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô Fabric (‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏à‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô)**: ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏ü‡∏µ‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà ‡πÜ ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Fabric ‡πÅ‡∏≠‡∏õ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏õ‡∏¥‡∏î‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô `android/gradle.properties`: ```properties react-native-use-fabric=false ``` 4. **‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Clean Build**: ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡πÑ‡∏•‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏µ‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß ‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ñ‡∏≠‡∏°‡πÑ‡∏û‡∏•‡πå‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà‡∏≠‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏•‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ: ```bash cd android ./gradlew clean cd .. npx react-native run-android ``` 5. **‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏£‡∏∏‡πà‡∏ô‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≤ (‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô)**: ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏á‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏Å‡∏•‡∏±‡∏ö‡πÑ‡∏õ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏£‡∏∏‡πà‡∏ô‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏≠‡∏õ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ: ```bash npm install --save react-native-view-shot@9.0.0 // ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏£‡∏∏‡πà‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏¢‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏î‡∏µ ``` ### ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏û‡∏ö‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏° - **‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£**: - ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πá‡∏Ñ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏´‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≤ GitHub ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á The error you‚Äôre encountering indicates that the Gradle build process cannot find the `com.tom_roush:pdfbox-android:2.0.0` dependency. Here are the steps to address this issue effectively: ### Step 1: Add the Dependency in `build.gradle` 1. **Open `android/app/build.gradle`:** Navigate to your React Native project directory, and open `android/app/build.gradle`. 2. **Add the Missing Dependency:** Inside the `dependencies` block, ensure you have the following line: ```groovy dependencies { implementation 'com.tom_roush:pdfbox-android:2.0.0' // other dependencies } ``` ### Step 2: Update Repositories in `build.gradle` 3. **Open `android/build.gradle`:** Now, open `android/build.gradle` (the project-level `build.gradle`). 4. **Check Repositories:** Ensure you have `mavenCentral()` and optionally `jcenter()` in the `repositories` section. It should look like this: ```groovy allprojects { repositories { google() mavenCentral() // Include this for most libraries jcenter() // Optional, may be needed for some older libraries } } ``` ### Step 3: Sync Gradle and Clean Build 5. **Sync Gradle:** After making these changes, sync your Gradle files. If you're using Android Studio, you can click on "Sync Now" when prompted or run the command below in your terminal: ```bash cd android ./gradlew sync ``` 6. **Clean and Rebuild:** Clean your project and rebuild it to ensure all changes are applied correctly: ```bash ./gradlew clean cd .. react-native run-android ``` ### Step 4: Verify Dependency Availability 7. **Check Repository for Dependency:** Verify that the `pdfbox-android` library is available in the repositories you're using. You can do this by searching for it on [Maven Central](https://search.maven.org/) or the [JCenter](https://bintray.com/bintray/jcenter). If `com.tom_roush:pdfbox-android:2.0.0` is not available, you might want to use an alternative version or find a different library that provides similar functionality. ### Step 5: Alternative Option 8. **Specify Alternative Versions:** If the required version is not available, you can try using a different version if applicable. Check the documentation or repository for available versions. Example with a different version: ```groovy implementation 'com.tom_roush:pdfbox-android:1.8.8' // Change the version if needed ``` ### Conclusion Following these steps should resolve the dependency issue you're facing. If you continue having problems, please check the logs for any additional clues or errors, and feel free to reach out for further assistance!

`external_labels` ‡πÉ‡∏ô Prometheus ‡∏°‡∏±‡∏Å‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÅ‡∏ô‡πà‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏∏‡πÅ‡∏´‡∏•‡πà‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏ô ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏ó‡∏±‡πà‡∏ß‡πÑ‡∏õ‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏ï‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏á‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏ñ‡∏∏‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì ### ‡πÅ‡∏´‡∏•‡πà‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `external_labels` 1. **‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏ï‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á:** ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤ `external_labels` ‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö Prometheus ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡∏∞‡∏ó‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏™‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÅ‡∏ß‡∏î‡∏•‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏±‡∏™‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô ```yaml external_labels: cluster: "prod-cluster-01" # ‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏±‡∏™‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î env: "production" # ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏∏‡∏™‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÅ‡∏ß‡∏î‡∏•‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏° ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô production, staging, development ``` ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏ï‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏£‡∏π‡πâ‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÉ‡∏î 2. **‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏ï‡πÇ‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥:** ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÇ‡∏ã‡∏•‡∏π‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏±‡∏™‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á Kubernetes ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ Openshift ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å label ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ annotation ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Kubernetes ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å - Metadata ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Namespace ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ Service ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà - Label ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏•‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô Pods ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ Deployments ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πà‡∏á‡∏ä‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏™‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏†‡∏ó‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏≠‡∏õ‡∏û‡∏•‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô 3. **‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏ö CI/CD:** ‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏û‡∏±‡∏í‡∏ô‡∏≤ (Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment) ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤ `external_labels` ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏™‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÅ‡∏ß‡∏î‡∏•‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏° (Environment Variables) ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏ö CI/CD ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô Git branch, build ID ‡∏Ø‡∏•‡∏Ø ### ‡∏™‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏õ `external_labels` ‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏ï‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏ï‡πÇ‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥ ‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÅ‡∏´‡∏•‡πà‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏°‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÉ‡∏î‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏ï‡πÇ‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥ ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏£‡∏™‡∏∞‡∏ó‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏á‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤ ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏â‡∏û‡∏≤‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏à‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏° ‡πÅ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö! üöÄ

The build failure you're facing again relates to the `react-native-blob-util` package. Specifically, errors regarding the `ReactNativeBlobUtilPackage` class indicate that the implementation does not match the expected structure for React Native packages, possibly due to breaking changes in the React Native API or the library itself. ### Troubleshooting Steps 1. **Check Library Compatibility**: - Ensure that you are using a **compatible version** of `react-native-blob-util` that supports your version of React Native. Since React Native has evolved, many libraries need to be updated to remain compatible. If you have not done so already, check the current stable versions available: ```bash npm show react-native-blob-util versions --json ``` You might want to downgrade or upgrade the package depending on the compatibility with your React Native version. 2. **Install Missing Dependencies**: - Ensure you have installed all required native assets for `react-native-blob-util`. Sometimes missing native dependencies can cause issues. - If you had a previous version installed, you might also consider removing and reinstalling it: ```bash npm uninstall react-native-blob-util npm install react-native-blob-util ``` 3. **Edit Java Implementation**: If you're comfortable modifying the library source in your `node_modules`, you can fix the implementation temporarily until the library is officially updated. - Open the following file: ``` C:\NooMixx\OTC_Projects\techserve\poc\react-bluetooth-printer\node_modules\react-native-blob-util\android\src\main\java\com\ReactNativeBlobUtil\ReactNativeBlobUtilPackage.java ``` Make sure your class correctly extends `ReactPackage`. For instance, if `ReactPackage` has a new location or has been changed in newer versions, adjust imports accordingly: ```java import com.facebook.react.ReactPackage; // Ensure this import is correct public class ReactNativeBlobUtilPackage extends ReactPackage { // Implement or reference required methods } ``` Confirm that methods needed (like `createNativeModules`) are also correctly defined. 4. **Update Your Dependencies**: If you find your version of React Native is not compatible with the latest version of `react-native-blob-util`, consider also updating React Native or using another library if applicable. ### Alternative: Use `react-native-fs` If `react-native-blob-util` continues to cause issues, you might consider switching to `react-native-fs`, which handles file system access in React Native and is widely supported. 1. Install `react-native-fs`: ```bash npm install react-native-fs ``` or ```bash yarn add react-native-fs ``` 2. Update your codebase to accommodate `react-native-fs` instead of `react-native-blob-util`. ### Step 5: Clear Build Cache After making any changes, it‚Äôs essential to clean your project: ```bash cd android ./gradlew clean ``` Then rebuild your project: ```bash cd .. npx react-native run-android ``` ### Summary The errors you're facing with `react-native-blob-util` likely arise from a mismatch between the expected and provided implementations. By verifying compatibility, adjusting imports, and potentially switching libraries, you should be able to resolve these issues. If the problem persists, please provide additional details about your current React Native version and any modifications you made to the library.

Certainly! Below is an example setup for a StatefulSet in Kubernetes that incorporates Thanos, Prometheus, and MinIO. This example is simplified for clarity and assumes you have a working Kubernetes cluster. You would also need Helm installed if you choose to use it for simpler deployments. ### 1. **Set Up MinIO**: First, let‚Äôs create a Deployment for MinIO. This will run the MinIO server, and we‚Äôll expose it using a Service. ```yaml apiVersion: v1 kind: Service metadata: name: minio-service labels: app: minio spec: ports: - port: 9000 targetPort: 9000 selector: app: minio --- apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: minio labels: app: minio spec: replicas: 1 selector: matchLabels: app: minio template: metadata: labels: app: minio spec: containers: - name: minio image: minio/minio args: ["server", "/data"] ports: - containerPort: 9000 env: - name: MINIO_ACCESS_KEY value: "minioadmin" - name: MINIO_SECRET_KEY value: "minioadmin" volumeMounts: - mountPath: /data name: minio-persistent-storage volumes: - name: minio-persistent-storage persistentVolumeClaim: claimName: minio-pvc --- apiVersion: v1 kind: PersistentVolumeClaim metadata: name: minio-pvc spec: accessModes: - ReadWriteOnce resources: requests: storage: 10Gi ``` ### 2. **Set Up Prometheus**: Next, create a StatefulSet for Prometheus. This will also expose the Prometheus service. ```yaml apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: StatefulSet metadata: name: prometheus spec: serviceName: "prometheus" replicas: 1 selector: matchLabels: app: prometheus template: metadata: labels: app: prometheus spec: containers: - name: prometheus image: prom/prometheus:latest ports: - containerPort: 9090 volumeMounts: - name: prometheus-storage mountPath: /prometheus args: - --config.file=/etc/prometheus/prometheus.yml - --storage.tsdb.path=/prometheus - --web.listen-address=:9090 - --web.external-url=http://<YOUR_PROMETHEUS_IP>:9090 volumes: - name: prometheus-storage persistentVolumeClaim: claimName: prometheus-pvc --- apiVersion: v1 kind: PersistentVolumeClaim metadata: name: prometheus-pvc spec: accessModes: - ReadWriteOnce resources: requests: storage: 10Gi ``` ### 3. **Set Up Thanos Sidecar**: Integrate Thanos with Prometheus by adding a Thanos Sidecar to the StatefulSet. ```yaml apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: StatefulSet metadata: name: prometheus spec: # ... [existing spec configuration] template: metadata: labels: app: prometheus spec: containers: - name: prometheus # ... [existing prometheus configuration] - name: thanos-sidecar image: thanosio/thanos:v0.20.0 args: - sidecar - --http-address=0.0.0.0:19191 - --grpc-address=0.0.0.0:19190 - --prometheus.url=http://localhost:9090 - --objstore.config=$(OBJSTORE_CONFIG) - --tsdb.path=/prometheus env: - name: OBJSTORE_CONFIG value: | { "type": "S3", "config": { "bucket": "<YOUR_BUCKET_NAME>", "endpoint": "minio-service:9000", "access_key": "minioadmin", "secret_key": "minioadmin", "secure": false } } ``` ### 4. **Deploy the Services**: You can apply these manifests to your Kubernetes cluster using `kubectl`: ```bash kubectl apply -f minio-deployment.yaml kubectl apply -f prometheus-statefulset.yaml ``` ### 5. **Access Prometheus and Thanos**: 1. **Access MinIO** at `http://<YOUR_MINIO_IP>:9000` with the credentials provided (`minioadmin` / `minioadmin`). 2. **Access Prometheus** at `http://<YOUR_PROMETHEUS_IP>:9090`. 3. For Thanos, it runs on port 19191 (HTTP) and 19190 (gRPC). ### Note: - Adjust `<YOUR_PROMETHEUS_IP>` and `<YOUR_MINIO_IP>` as necessary based on your Kubernetes setup. - Make sure to configure RBAC and network policies as per your security needs. Feel free to ask if you need more details or if there's something you'd like to explore deeper! üòä

Hello! üòä It sounds like you're encountering an issue with the `cross-env` command in your project, which is commonly used in Node.js environments to set environment variables in a cross-platform way. Here are a few steps you can take to resolve this issue: 1. **Install `cross-env`**: First, make sure that `cross-env` is installed in your project. You can do this by running the following command in your project directory: ```bash npm install cross-env --save-dev ``` or if you're using Yarn: ```bash yarn add cross-env --dev ``` 2. **Check Your Scripts**: If you're using `cross-env` in an npm script (like in your `package.json`), ensure that you're referring to it correctly. For example: ```json "scripts": { "start": "cross-env NODE_ENV=production node app.js" } ``` 3. **PATH Issues**: Sometimes, the issue might be due to the PATH not including the location where `cross-env` is installed. If you installed it locally, it might be in the `node_modules/.bin` directory. Ensure that your terminal session can access it. 4. **Global Installation**: If you need `cross-env` globally (not often recommended), you can install it globally with: ```bash npm install -g cross-env ``` 5. **Use Directly**: If you do not want to use `cross-env`, you can set the environment variables directly in a way that's appropriate for your operating system. For example, on Windows, you can use the following syntax: ```bash set NODE_ENV=production && node app.js ``` 6. **Check for Typos**: Make sure there are no typos in your commands or scripts. If you can provide more context, like the Operating System you're using or the specific command you're trying to run, I‚Äôd be happy to help further! üöÄ
thread_2YnkEil43IGExt8bGvHO4uG9
3:45 PM
The error message you're encountering indicates that the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is unable to allocate sufficient memory for the Gradle daemon process. Specifically, it states: ``` Could not reserve enough space for 2097152KB object heap ``` This suggests that the JVM is unable to allocate the 2GB of memory requested (2,048 MB) for the Java application due to insufficient available memory on your machine. Here are some steps to resolve this issue: ### Steps to Fix the Error 1. **Check Available Memory**: Ensure that your machine has enough free memory. You can check available memory in the Task Manager (Windows) or Activity Monitor (Mac). If your system is running low on RAM, consider closing unnecessary applications. 2. **Reduce JVM Memory Allocation**: If your machine's memory is limited, you can reduce the maximum heap size allocated to the JVM in your Gradle configuration. - Locate your `gradle.properties` file, commonly found in your project root directory or in the `.gradle` directory in your user home directory. - Add or modify the following line: ```properties org.gradle.jvmargs=-Xmx1024m ``` This sets the maximum heap size to 1GB. Adjust this value according to your system's capacity. 3. **Increase System Memory (if applicable)**: If you consistently hit memory limits, consider upgrading your system‚Äôs RAM if it‚Äôs feasible. 4. **Disable the Gradle Daemon Temporarily**: If you still encounter issues, you can disable the Gradle daemon for a single build: ```shell ./gradlew --no-daemon build ``` 5. **Run Gradle with Debug Options**: If the problem persists, run Gradle commands with the `--stacktrace`, `--info`, or `--debug` options to get more detailed output that may help identify the source of the problem: ```shell ./gradlew build --info ``` 6. **Update Java Version**: Ensure you are using an up-to-date version of the Java JDK rather than JRE. You are currently referencing: ``` C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre1.8.0_431 ``` It is recommended to install the latest JDK, e.g., JDK 8 or higher. 7. **Check for Conflicts in JVM options**: Make sure your `gradle.properties` file or any other JVM argument files don't contain conflicting or unsupported JVM options. ### Testing the Changes After making these changes, try running your Gradle build command again. If the issue persists, please provide the updated error logs for further assistance.

2:34 PM
The error message you're encountering indicates that the Java command is not being recognized properly or that there's an issue with your Java installation. The `--version` option is typically used to display the version of Java, and seeing an error suggests that the command or the installation may be problematic. ### Here are some steps to diagnose and fix the issue: #### Step 1: Check Your Java Installation 1. **Ensure Java is Installed**: - Go to your system's Control Panel > Programs > Programs and Features and see if Java is installed. 2. **Reinstall Java (If Necessary)**: - If Java is not installed, download the latest version of the Java Development Kit (JDK) from the [Oracle JDK website](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/javase-jdk11-downloads.html) or [AdoptOpenJDK](https://adoptopenjdk.net/). - Follow the instructions to install it. #### Step 2: Verify the Installation Path Make sure that your `JAVA_HOME` variable is set correctly to point to the right Java installation directory. Here‚Äôs how to check: **For Windows**: 1. Open a new Command Prompt. 2. Type the following command: ```bash echo %JAVA_HOME% ``` Ensure it points to the JDK installation folder, such as `C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-<version>`. 3. If it‚Äôs incorrect, follow these steps to set it: - Open "Environment Variables" in System Properties. - In the "System variables" section, locate `JAVA_HOME`, modify it to the correct path. - Also, ensure `%JAVA_HOME%\bin` is included in your `Path` variable. #### Step 3: Verify the PATH Variable Make sure Java is in your system's PATH: 1. In Command Prompt, run: ```bash echo %PATH% ``` Check if you can see a segment similar to `C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-<version>\bin`. 2. If the path to the `bin` directory of the JDK is not there, you'll need to add it: - Open "Environment Variables" again. - Modify the `Path` variable and add a new entry: ``` %JAVA_HOME%\bin ``` #### Step 4: Test Java Command After setting the environment variables, open a new Command Prompt window (to ensure the changes take effect) and run: ```bash java -version ``` This should now show you the installed version of Java. ### Additional Suggestions - If you have multiple Java installations, there might be a conflict. Ensure that only the necessary Java version is in your PATH. - Restart your computer after making changes, if necessary. If you continue to experience issues, please provide any error messages you receive, and I can assist further! üòä

‡∏™‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏™‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏∞! üåº ‡∏¢‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏∞ ‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏û‡∏π‡∏î‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á Gradle ‡πÉ‡∏ô Android Studio ‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏ñ‡∏≠‡∏∞! ### Gradle ‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏∞‡πÑ‡∏£? Let's refactor your code for better readability and efficiency. Here are two main improvements we can make: 1. **Reduce Duplication**: As the construction of `ProductVatRequest` is similar in both branches of the if statement, we can create a base instance and then modify it according to the condition. 2. **Use Null Propagation Consistently**: We can directly use the null-conditional operator for `DiscountBenefitProducts`. Here‚Äôs the refactored code: ```csharp var productVatRequest = new ProductVatRequest { ReferenceKey = $"{product.Code}-{product.SaleUnit.Name}", AmountIncludeVat = GetTotalAmount(product.SaleUnit) }; if (product.SaleUnit.DiscountBenefitProducts != null) { productVatRequest.DiscountPerItemKey = product.SaleUnit.DiscountBenefitProducts.Sum(x => x.DiscountIncludeVat).ToString(); } vatRequest.Products.Add(productVatRequest); ``` ### Explanations: 1. **Creation of `productVatRequest` Instance**: - This is done once, and shared properties like `ReferenceKey` and `AmountIncludeVat` are set initially. 2. **Conditional Assignment**: - Instead of rewriting all shared properties in both branches, we simply add the `DiscountPerItemKey` if `DiscountBenefitProducts` is not null. ### Benefits of the Refactor: - **Readability**: Reduces visual clutter by limiting repetitive code. - **Maintainability**: Easier to modify the core object if properties change in the future. - **Consistency**: Using a single instance for similar tasks makes the code cleaner. Feel free to adapt this pattern for other similar blocks of code!

Below are implementations in a few common programming languages: ### C# ```csharp var result = product?.SaleUnit?.DiscountBenefitProducts != null ? SumValues() : "0"; ``` ### JavaScript ```javascript let result = product && product.SaleUnit && product.SaleUnit.DiscountBenefitProducts ? sumValues() : "0"; ``` ### Python ```python result = sum_values() if product.SaleUnit and product.SaleUnit.DiscountBenefitProducts is not None else "0" ``` ### Explanation - **Null Check**: Each example first checks if `DiscountBenefitProducts` is not null (or equivalent). - **Sum Function**: `SumValues()` or `sumValues()` is a placeholder for whatever sum function or logic you are using in your application. You should replace it with the actual logic needed to calculate the sum of values. - **Result Assignment**: If the condition is met (i.e., `DiscountBenefitProducts` is not null), the sum is returned; otherwise, "0" is returned. To select the sum of `DiscountTotalIncludeVat` from the `DiscountBenefitProducts` list in a clearer manner, you can keep your current code which is already valid. However, if you're looking for ways to enhance readability or ensure that you're summing only certain values based on additional conditions, here's a refined approach: ### Option 1: Existing Code Your current code works as follows: ```csharp DiscountPerItemKey = product.SaleUnit.DiscountBenefitProducts.Select(x => x.DiscountTotalIncludeVat).Sum(); ``` ### Option 2: Improved Readability with `Sum` You can directly use the `Sum` method on the collection without `Select` if you're simply summing a property: ```csharp DiscountPerItemKey = product.SaleUnit.DiscountBenefitProducts.Sum(x => x.DiscountTotalIncludeVat); ``` This approach simplifies your code and enhances readability by directly summing the property. ### Option 3: Conditional Summing If there are conditions (for example, only summing items that meet a specific criterion), you can use `Where` to filter the items: ```csharp DiscountPerItemKey = product.SaleUnit.DiscountBenefitProducts .Where(x => x.SomeCondition) // Replace `SomeCondition` with your actual condition .Sum(x => x.DiscountTotalIncludeVat); ``` ### Summary - The direct use of `Sum` on the collection can improve legibility. - Consider conditionally summing if there are specific filters needed. Feel free to share any additional context if you have specific requirements or conditions for summation!
thread_WV7WP9rOh3fdKBIu733T4RjN
10:34 AM
In C#, when defining a property with default values, you can achieve this in a couple of ways. If you're using a required property and want to set a default value of `0.00`, there are no direct ways to set a default explicitly in the property definition with the `required` modifier. However, you can initialize it in the constructor or use a backing field. Here's how you can implement this using a constructor: ```csharp public class YourModel { public required decimal DiscountAmountIncludeVat { get; set; } public YourModel() { DiscountAmountIncludeVat = 0.00m; // Setting the default value to 0.00 } } ``` ### Explanation: - In the constructor, you initialize the `DiscountAmountIncludeVat` property to `0.00` (use `m` to denote that it's a decimal). - The `required` keyword indicates that the property must be set before the object is fully constructed, ensuring that it will always be assigned a value. Alternatively, if you don't need the `required` modifier and just want to ensure that it defaults to `0.00`, you can use the backing field approach like this: ```csharp public class YourModel { private decimal _discountAmountIncludeVat = 0.00m; // Default value set here public decimal DiscountAmountIncludeVat { get => _discountAmountIncludeVat; set => _discountAmountIncludeVat = value; } } ``` ### Summary: - The best practice for required properties is to initialize them in the constructor. - If you prefer a backing field for initialization, you can set the default value directly where you declare it. Choose the approach that best fits your requirements!
