Your `GenerateFiDocument` method has a small issue related to creating a list from the grouped sales orders. The line that constructs `SalesOrderNos` should convert the collection of lists into a flat list of sales order numbers, rather than just referencing the values without calling `.ToList()`. Additionally, it's good practice to ensure that your method properly initializes all relevant properties of the `FiDocument`. Here‚Äôs how you can properly implement this method: ### Updated `GenerateFiDocument` Method ```csharp public FiDocument GenerateFiDocument(List<SalesOrder> salesOrders, uint runningNumber) { // Group sales orders by SalesOrderNo var groupedSalesOrders = salesOrders.GroupBy(s => s.SalesOrderNo) .ToDictionary(g => g.Key, g => g.ToList()); // Create a new FiDocument FiDocument fi = new FiDocument { CreatedDate = DateTime.Now, Status = DocumentStatus.waitingForPost, // Flatten the list of sales order numbers and convert to List SalesOrderNos = groupedSalesOrders.Keys.ToList(), RunningNumber = runningNumber // Assuming this property exists }; // Additional logic to populate other properties of FiDocument // For example, you might want to process items from groupedSalesOrders return fi; } ``` ### Key Updates and Explanations: 1. **Values to Keys**: Instead of trying to take `ListSalesOrder.Values.ToList`, use `groupedSalesOrders.Keys.ToList()`. This makes sure that you're adding the unique `SalesOrderNo` values to `SalesOrderNos`. 2. **Running Number**: Make sure that if `FiDocument` has a property called `RunningNumber`, you set it to the passed `runningNumber`. 3. **Additional Properties**: If `FiDocument` has other properties that need to be initialized based on the `SalesOrders`, you should include that logic in this method. Right now, only `CreatedDate`, `Status`, and `SalesOrderNos` are being initialized. 4. **Documentation**: Consider adding XML comments to describe the method and its parameters to enhance maintainability and readability. ### Complete Code Sample The method now creates a `FiDocument` with the correct structure and handles sales order numbers correctly. Here‚Äôs the full stand-alone method including comments for clarity: ```csharp public FiDocument GenerateFiDocument(List<SalesOrder> salesOrders, uint runningNumber) { // Group sales orders by SalesOrderNo var groupedSalesOrders = salesOrders.GroupBy(s => s.SalesOrderNo) .ToDictionary(g => g.Key, g => g.ToList()); // Create a new FiDocument FiDocument fi = new FiDocument { CreatedDate = DateTime.Now, Status = DocumentStatus.waitingForPost, // Extract unique SalesOrderNos to SalesOrderNos property SalesOrderNos = groupedSalesOrders.Keys.ToList(), RunningNumber = runningNumber // Set the running number if needed }; // Additional logic to populate other fields of fi based on sales orders can go here return fi; } ``` ### Testing the Method Make sure to create unit tests to verify that: - `SalesOrderNos` contains the correct values. - Any additional properties of `FiDocument` are populated correctly. - Edge cases (like an empty list of sales orders) are handled without exceptions. With this approach, your `GenerateFiDocument` method should effectively create and return a `FiDocument` with the desired properties properly initialized.

`git pull` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ `git pull --rebase` ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≤‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏à‡∏à‡∏∏‡∏ö‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å repository ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏¢‡∏∞‡πÑ‡∏Å‡∏• (remote repository) ‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÅ‡∏ï‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô ‡∏î‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡πÅ‡∏ï‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏£: ### 1. **git pull** - **‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á:** `git pull` - **‡∏û‡∏§‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏£‡∏°:** - ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å remote repository ‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á repository ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏° (merge) ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏à‡∏à‡∏∏‡∏ö‡∏±‡∏ô - ‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `git pull` ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á commit ‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏ì‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô remote repository ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢ ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô commit ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ "merge commit" - ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á: ``` * Merge branch 'main' of origin into feature-branch |\ | * Commit from remote | * Another commit from remote * | Local commit |/ * Previous commit ``` ### 2. **git pull --rebase** - **‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á:** `git pull --rebase` - **‡∏û‡∏§‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏£‡∏°:** - ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å remote repository ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÅ‡∏ó‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥ merge ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ rebase - ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ rebase ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ commit ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì (‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ push ‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á remote) ‡∏¢‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏¢ (reapply) ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å commit ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å remote ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á (history) ‡∏™‡∏∞‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ merge commit - ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á: ``` * Local commit (new position after rebase) * Previous commit * Remote commit (from pull) * Another remote commit (from pull) ``` ### ‡∏™‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏õ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡πÅ‡∏ï‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏Å - **History**: - `git pull`: ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á merge commit ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏î‡∏π‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ã‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏ã‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô - `git pull --rebase`: ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏™‡∏∞‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ö‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏¢ ‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏ß‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏° (merge commit) - **‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏™‡∏∞‡∏î‡∏ß‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô**: - ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ö‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `git pull --rebase` ‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏´‡πá‡∏ô‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏û‡∏±‡∏í‡∏ô‡∏≤‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏™‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ô commit ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å merging - **Conflict Resolution**: - ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏Ç‡∏±‡∏î‡πÅ‡∏¢‡πâ‡∏á (conflicts) ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏Å‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏Ç‡∏±‡∏î‡πÅ‡∏¢‡πâ‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏•‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô ‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `rebase` ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö conflict ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏•‡∏≥‡∏î‡∏±‡∏ö commit ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì ### ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏î - **git pull**: ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡∏°‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ commit ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡πà‡∏á‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏ö‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≠‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ú‡∏π‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô - **git pull --rebase**: ‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏£‡πà‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ commit ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏¢‡∏∏‡πà‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏¢‡∏¥‡∏á ### ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏£‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏á ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏à‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ `git rebase` ‡∏à‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÅ‡∏ô‡πà‡πÉ‡∏à‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏™‡πà‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á remote repository ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡πÄ‡∏ô‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ rebase ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô commit ‡∏Ç‡∏ì‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ push ‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á remote ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ rebase ‡∏ö‡∏ô commit ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡πà‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á remote ‡πÅ‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏ô‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏±‡∏î‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏´‡∏•‡∏µ‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏¢‡∏∏‡πà‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏¢‡∏¥‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏û‡∏±‡∏í‡∏ô‡∏≤. ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏≠‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏â‡∏û‡∏≤‡∏∞‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏ì‡∏µ‡πÉ‡∏î ‡πÜ ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢!

‡∏™‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏™‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö! üòä ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô `Func` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô ‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏£‡πà‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö Entity Framework ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô `Expression<Func<T, bool>>` ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡∏°‡∏µ‡πÅ‡∏ô‡∏ß‡∏ó‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏î‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ: ### ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô `GetListAsyncByCondition` ‡∏™‡∏°‡∏°‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏•‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠ `Product` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏°‡∏ö‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥ `Id`, `Name`, ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ `Price` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏¥‡∏ï‡∏†‡∏±‡∏ì‡∏ë‡πå‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏ó‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö 100. ```csharp public class Product { public int Id { get; set; } public string Name { get; set; } public decimal Price { get; set; } } public async Task<List<Product>> GetAffordableProductsAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken) { // ‡∏ô‡∏¥‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Expression Expression<Func<Product, bool>> filter = product => product.Price <= 100; // ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô GetListAsyncByCondition var affordableProducts = await GetListAsyncByCondition(filter, cancellationToken); return affordableProducts; } ``` ### ‡∏≠‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏î 1. **‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏•**: ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏¥‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏™ `Product` ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏°‡∏ö‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á ‡πÜ ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏• 2. **‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô `GetAffordableProductsAsync`**: - ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏¥‡∏û‡∏à‡∏ô‡πå (expression) ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏á `Product` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏ó‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö 100 ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `Expression<Func<Product, bool>>`. - ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô `GetListAsyncByCondition` ‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô `filter` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏¥‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÑ‡∏ß‡πâ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏™‡πà‡∏á `cancellationToken` ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á - ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏¥‡∏ï‡∏†‡∏±‡∏ì‡∏ë‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç ### ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡πÇ‡∏¢‡∏ä‡∏ô‡πå‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Expression - **‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏•‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏≤ (Deferred Execution)**: ‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏ß‡∏•‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô `ToListAsync()`, ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ó‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡∏™‡∏π‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏•‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏ó‡∏£‡∏±‡∏û‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏£ - **‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏î‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏∑‡∏î‡∏´‡∏¢‡∏∏‡πà‡∏ô**: ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢ ‡πÜ ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏ô‡∏¥‡∏û‡∏à‡∏ô‡πå ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏î‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô ‡∏´‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏à‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô `GetListAsyncByCondition` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á ‡πÜ ‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö! ‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏° ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏™‡πà‡∏ß‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏´‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏° ‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö!

‡πÅ‡∏ô‡πà‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏ô! ‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏π‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô `GetListAsyncByCondition` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÅ‡∏ä‡∏£‡πå‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏∞ üòä ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏™‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÅ‡∏ß‡∏î‡∏•‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏ö‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏ô ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÄ‡∏´‡πá‡∏ô‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô ### ‡πÄ‡∏™‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô 1. **‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏•** 2. **‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á DbContext** 3. **‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Generic Repository** 4. **‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Service** 5. **‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏õ‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏°‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏Å** ### 1. ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏• ‡∏™‡∏°‡∏°‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏µ‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏• `Product` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏≤: ```csharp public class Product { public int Id { get; set; } public string Name { get; set; } public decimal Price { get; set; } } ``` ### 2. ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á DbContext ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á `DbContext` ‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•: ```csharp using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore; public class AppDbContext : DbContext { public DbSet<Product> Products { get; set; } public AppDbContext(DbContextOptions<AppDbContext> options) : base(options) { } } ``` ### 3. ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Generic Repository ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏™ `GenericRepository` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô `GetListAsyncByCondition`: ```csharp using System; using System.Collections.Generic; using System.Linq.Expressions; using System.Threading; using System.Threading.Tasks; using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore; public class GenericRepository<T> where T : class { private readonly AppDbContext _dbContext; public GenericRepository(AppDbContext dbContext) { _dbContext = dbContext; } public async Task<List<T>> GetListAsyncByCondition(Expression<Func<T, bool>> filter, CancellationToken cancellationToken) { return await _dbContext.Set<T>() .Where(filter) // ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ filter ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å parameter .ToListAsync(cancellationToken); // ‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç } } ``` ### 4. ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Service ‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏™‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô `GetListAsyncByCondition`: ```csharp using System.Collections.Generic; using System.Linq.Expressions; using System.Threading; using System.Threading.Tasks; public class ProductService { private readonly GenericRepository<Product> _productRepository; public ProductService(GenericRepository<Product> productRepository) { _productRepository = productRepository; } public async Task<List<Product>> GetProductsAbovePriceAsync(decimal price, CancellationToken cancellationToken) { Expression<Func<Product, bool>> filter = product => product.Price > price; // ‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î return await _productRepository.GetListAsyncByCondition(filter, cancellationToken); } } ``` ### 5. ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏õ‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏°‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏Å ‡∏™‡∏∏‡∏î‡∏ó‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ô `Program.cs` ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏ô `Main`: ```csharp using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore; using System; using System.Collections.Generic; using System.Threading; using System.Threading.Tasks; public class Program { public static async Task Main(string[] args) { var options = new DbContextOptionsBuilder<AppDbContext>() .UseInMemoryDatabase(databaseName: "TestDatabase") // ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏ô‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏à‡∏≥ .Options; using (var context = new AppDbContext(options)) { // ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á context.Products.AddRange( new Product { Name = "Product 1", Price = 50 }, new Product { Name = "Product 2", Price = 150 }, new Product { Name = "Product 3", Price = 200 } ); context.SaveChanges(); // ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á instance ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Repository ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ Service var productRepository = new GenericRepository<Product>(context); var productService = new ProductService(productRepository); var cancellationToken = new CancellationToken(); // ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡∏π‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ 100 List<Product> expensiveProducts = await productService.GetProductsAbovePriceAsync(100, cancellationToken); // ‡πÅ‡∏™‡∏î‡∏á‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå Console.WriteLine("Products with Price greater than 100:"); foreach (var product in expensiveProducts) { Console.WriteLine($"Product Name: {product.Name}, Price: {product.Price}"); } } } } ``` ### ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏´‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏á ‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏õ‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏°‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏´‡πá‡∏ô‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏ã‡∏•‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÅ‡∏™‡∏î‡∏á‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏≤: ``` Products with Price greater than 100: Product Name: Product 2, Price: 150 Product Name: Product 3, Price: 200 ``` ### ‡∏™‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏õ ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÅ‡∏™‡∏î‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏´‡πá‡∏ô‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Å‡πå‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô `GetListAsyncByCondition` ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏î‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å Database ‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ó‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ö‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏¢ ‡∏´‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏à‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏ô‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô! ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏•‡∏∂‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏à‡∏∏‡∏î ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏∞! üåü

3:19 PM
To query documents that do not have the `saleUnit.code` field and then add that field with an empty string to those documents in MongoDB, you can use the following `updateMany` command: ```javascript db.yourCollectionName.updateMany( { "saleUnit.code": { $exists: false } }, // Find documents without the 'saleUnit.code' field { $set: { "saleUnit.code": "" } } // Set 'saleUnit.code' to an empty string ); ``` ### Explanation: 1. **`yourCollectionName`**: Replace this with the actual name of your collection. 2. **`"saleUnit.code"`**: This specifies the nested field you want to check and update. 3. **`$exists: false`**: This condition filters documents that do not have the `saleUnit.code` field. 4. **`$set: { "saleUnit.code": "" }`**: This updates the matched documents by adding the `saleUnit.code` field and setting it to an empty string. ### Steps to Execute: 1. Open your MongoDB shell or a GUI tool (like MongoDB Compass). 2. Connect to your database and select the appropriate collection. 3. Run the above command. After executing this command, any documents that did not previously have the `saleUnit.code` field will now have it added with an empty string as its value. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, just let me know! üòä

To count the documents in a MongoDB collection that contain the letter "z" in the "code" field, you can use the following query: ```javascript db.collectionName.countDocuments({ code: /z/ }); ``` ### Explanation: - `db.collectionName`: Replace `collectionName` with the actual name of your collection. - `countDocuments()`: This function counts the documents that match the specified filter. - `{ code: /z/ }`: This condition uses a regular expression to find documents where the "code" field contains the letter "z". If you have more questions or need further clarification on MongoDB queries, feel free to ask! üòä

To write unit tests for your `GenerateFiDocument` method, we will need to ensure that the input data (`List<SalesOrder> salesOrder` and `long runningNumber`) is correctly structured. The test will verify that the method creates an instance of `FiDocument` and properly sets its properties, including checking the value produced by the `GroupPaymentToFI` method. ### Step 1: Define Necessary Classes Before implementing the unit test, ensure you have the necessary classes and enums defined, such as `FiDocument`, `ZBAPI_POST_DOCUMENT`, `DocumentStatus`, and `SalesOrder` with at least the `SalesOrderNo` property. An example might look like this: ```csharp public class FiDocument { public DateTime CreatedDate { get; set; } public DocumentStatus Status { get; set; } public List<string> SalesOrderNos { get; set; } public ZBAPI_POST_DOCUMENT ZBAPI_POST_DOCUMENT { get; set; } } public class ZBAPI_POST_DOCUMENT { public string INF { get; set; } public string WAIT { get; set; } public List<T_DATA> T_DATA { get; set; } } public enum DocumentStatus { waitingForPost, posted, canceled } public class SalesOrder { public string SalesOrderNo { get; set; } // Other properties... } ``` ### Step 2: Create the Unit Test Class Using NUnit and Moq, here‚Äôs how you can set up the unit tests for the `GenerateFiDocument` method: ```csharp using NUnit.Framework; using System; using System.Collections.Generic; using System.Linq; namespace YourNamespace.Tests { [TestFixture] public class YourServiceTests { private YourService _service; // Replace with the actual class name where GenerateFiDocument is implemented. [SetUp] public void Setup() { _service = new YourService(); // Initialize your service here. } [Test] public void GenerateFiDocument_ValidInput_ReturnsCorrectFiDocument() { // Arrange var salesOrders = new List<SalesOrder> { new SalesOrder { SalesOrderNo = "SO-001" }, new SalesOrder { SalesOrderNo = "SO-002" } }; long runningNumber = 123456; // example running number string expectedINF = "your_inf_value"; // Set this to the expected value of INF _service.INF = expectedINF; // Assuming INF is a property in YourService // Act FiDocument result = _service.GenerateFiDocument(salesOrders, runningNumber); // Assert Assert.NotNull(result); Assert.AreEqual(expectedINF, result.ZBAPI_POST_DOCUMENT.INF); Assert.AreEqual("", result.ZBAPI_POST_DOCUMENT.WAIT); Assert.AreEqual(2, result.SalesOrderNos.Count); Assert.Contains("SO-001", result.SalesOrderNos); Assert.Contains("SO-002", result.SalesOrderNos); Assert.AreEqual(DocumentStatus.waitingForPost, result.Status); // Assert the T_DATA is properly populated Assert.NotNull(result.ZBAPI_POST_DOCUMENT.T_DATA); // You can add additional assertions here based on the expected output of GroupPaymentToFI. } [Test] public void GenerateFiDocument_EmptySalesOrders_ReturnsFiDocumentWithEmptySalesOrderNos() { // Arrange var salesOrders = new List<SalesOrder>(); // Empty list long runningNumber = 123456; // Act FiDocument result = _service.GenerateFiDocument(salesOrders, runningNumber); // Assert Assert.NotNull(result); Assert.AreEqual(0, result.SalesOrderNos.Count); // Validate that sales order list is empty } } } ``` ### Explanation of the Tests 1. **Setup Method**: Initializes an instance of the service in the `Setup` method, ensuring a clean state before each test runs. 2. **GenerateFiDocument_ValidInput_ReturnsCorrectFiDocument**: - **Arrange**: Prepare a list of `SalesOrder` objects. Set the expected values for properties such as `INF`. - **Act**: Call the `GenerateFiDocument` method with the prepared data. - **Assert**: Validate that the result is not null, and check that its properties are set correctly based on the input. 3. **GenerateFiDocument_EmptySalesOrders_ReturnsFiDocumentWithEmptySalesOrderNos**: - **Test for edge case**: Verify that when provided an empty list of `SalesOrder`, the `SalesOrderNos` property of `FiDocument` is also empty. ### Running the Tests Compile and run these tests using your IDE‚Äôs testing features, making sure that NUnit is set up correctly in your test project. ### Additional Considerations - **Mocking Dependencies**: If `GenerateFiDocument` relies on external services or state, consider using mocking libraries like Moq to ensure those dependencies behave predictably during tests. - **Testing Different Scenarios**: You can extend these tests with additional cases, such as testing with different values for `runningNumber`, or checking how the service behaves with valid and invalid data. If you need any adjustments or further details on specific parts, feel free to ask!
thread_AVoQYw93RKiV4fhWQEQNOcVE
9:56 AM
To cancel all operations currently running in MongoDB, you can use the `db.killOp()` command which allows you to stop specific operations identified by their operation IDs. However, MongoDB does not provide a built-in command to cancel all operations simultaneously in one go. Instead, you can retrieve the list of current operations and then iteratively kill them. ### Steps to Cancel All Operations 1. **Get the List of Current Operations** using `db.currentOp()`. 2. **Iterate Over the Operations** to extract their operation IDs. 3. **Use `db.killOp()`** with each operation ID to terminate those operations. ### Example Code Here‚Äôs how you can do this: ```javascript // Step 1: Get the current operations var currentOps = db.currentOp(); // Step 2: Iterate over operations and kill them if (currentOps.inprog.length > 0) { currentOps.inprog.forEach(function(op) { // Check if the operation has an opId (it's not a lock or background operation) if (op.op == "query" || op.op == "update" || op.op == "insert" || op.op == "remove") { print("Killing operation with opId: " + op.id); db.killOp(op.id); } }); print("All running operations have been cancelled."); } else { print("No operations are currently running."); } ``` ### Important Notes: - **Be Cautious**: Killing operations can lead to data inconsistency or corruption if not handled properly, particularly for write operations. - **Check Dependencies**: Some operations may be interdependent or part of a larger operation. Always ensure that you understand the implications of cancelling operations. - **Non-blocking Operations**: This method can be used to terminate blocking operations but won't affect operations that are already completed or those that are not currently running (like background operations). ### Summary Using `db.currentOp()` in tandem with `db.killOp(op.id)` allows you to manage and cancel operations as needed. If you have more questions or need additional assistance, feel free to ask! üòä

To ensure the `MapSalesOrderToSdDocument` method behaves as expected, we need to carefully review and potentially refactor the grouping logic so that it aggregates `SalesOrder` and its `Products` correctly. ### Key Requirements 1. **Group `SalesOrder`** by relevant attributes. 2. **Consolidate `Products`** within each order based on their code. 3. Ensure that the output `IT_SALE_ITEM` only contains consolidated product entries (where products with the same code should be combined). ### Updated Implementation Let's modify the `MapSalesOrderToSdDocument` to handle these requirements correctly: ```csharp public List<SdDocument> MapSalesOrderToSdDocument(List<SalesOrder> salesOrders) { // Group SalesOrder by relevant attributes var groupedSalesOrders = salesOrders.GroupBy(x => new { x.DocumentDate, x.CompanyCode, x.SalesTeam.Code, x.PaymentType }); var sdDocuments = new List<SdDocument>(); foreach (var group in groupedSalesOrders) { var sdDocument = new SdDocument { Status = DoucumentStatus.waitingForPost, CreatedDate = DateTime.Now, SalesOrderNos = group.Select(x => x.SalesOrderNo).ToList(), I_INF = "OTCGRP", I_SALES_TYPE = "C02", I_WA_SALES_HEAD = new I_WA_SALES_HEAD { DOCUMENT_NUMBER = "0000000002000000", ORDER_ID = "", BILL_DATE = group.Key.DocumentDate, COMPANY = group.Key.CompanyCode, PAYMENT_TERM = "R000", SALES_CHNL = "CH02", SALES_GROUP = "006", SALES_TERRI = "", ORDER_REASON = "", STATUS = "6", DOC_DATE = group.Key.DocumentDate, SALES_OFFICE = "006", SALES_TEAM = group.FirstOrDefault().SalesTeam.Code, CUSTOMER_TYPE = "01", DELIV_PRIORITY = "", REQUEST_DATE = DateTime.Now.Date, TOTAL_AMOUNT = group.Sum(x => x.TotalNetAmountExcludeVat), TOTAL_VAT = group.Sum(x => x.VatAmount), WHT_AMOUNT = 0.00m, REMARK = "", IMPORT_DATE = null, IMPORT_TIME = null, DELIV_TIME = null, CREDIT_LIMIT = 0.00m, TRANSPORT_TYPE = "" }, IT_SALE_ITEM = group.SelectMany(order => order.Products) .GroupBy(p => p.Code) // Grouping products by their code .Select(productGroup => new IT_SALE_ITEM { ITEM_NUMBER = (sdDocument.IT_SALE_ITEM.Count + 1).ToString(), PLANT = "4601", STORAGE = "G038", MATERIAL = productGroup.Key, MATERIAL_DESC = productGroup.First().Name, // Assuming same name for grouped products QTY_SALES_UNIT = 0, SALES_UNIT = "", QTY_BASE_UNIT = productGroup.Sum(p => (p.BaseUnit.Quantity * p.BaseUnit.SalesRate) + (p.SaleUnit.Quantity * p.SaleUnit.SalesRate)), BASE_UNIT = productGroup.First().BaseUnit.Code, FREE = "", HIGH_ITEM = "", FREE_REASON = "", PROMO_NO = "", UNIT_PRICE = 0.00m, CURRENCY = "THB", PER = "", AMOUNT = productGroup.Sum(p => p.AmountExcludeVat), PROMO_DISC = 0.00m, SPEC_DISC = 0.00m, MANUAL_DISC = 0.00m, DC_ALLOWANCE = 0.00m, TAX_CODE = 7, TAX_AMOUNT = productGroup.Sum(p => p.VatAmount), NET_VALUE = productGroup.Sum(p => p.NetAmountExcludeVat), WHT_TYPE = "", WHT_CODE = "", WHT_BASE = 0, MATERIAL_SALES_TEXT = productGroup.First().TinyName, DATE_OF_MANUFACTURE = DateTime.Parse("0001-01-01"), REFERENCE_CODE = "00010101", WBS_STATISTIC = "" }).ToList() }; sdDocuments.Add(sdDocument); } return sdDocuments; } ``` ### Key Enhancements Made 1. **Grouping Products**: The products from all `SalesOrder` in each group are aggregated by their `Code` using `.GroupBy(p => p.Code)`. 2. **Consolidation Logic**: - The `AMOUNT`, `TAX_AMOUNT`, and `NET_VALUE` for each aggregated product entry in `IT_SALE_ITEM` is calculated as the sum of the relevant attributes from the grouped products. - `QTY_BASE_UNIT` now reflects the combined quantities of products sharing the same code. 3. **Dynamic ITEM_NUMBER**: The `ITEM_NUMBER` is calculated based on the count of items already added to the list. ### Testing the Implementation Now that the `MapSalesOrderToSdDocument` method properly consolidates product information, your test case should be able to validate that `IT_SALE_ITEM` contains the correct number of items: - The test will assert that the expected single product in `IT_SALE_ITEM` accurately reflects the combined totals from multiple sales orders. ### Example Test ```csharp [Fact] public async Task MapSalesOrderToSdDocument_ReturnDataCorrectly() { // Set up mock data... // (Similar to the previous examples, ensuring products have the same Code) var result = _service.MapSalesOrderToSdDocument(mockSalesOrders); // Assertions for the result based on grouped products... } ``` With these changes, the `MapSalesOrderToSdDocument` function should now properly consolidate the sales orders and their products as intended. If you need further adjustments or have specific scenarios in mind, feel free to share them!

Got it! If you want the output to show only the `description` field from the `productTemp` in the results, you can use the `$project` stage to specify which fields to include in your output. Here‚Äôs how you can modify the aggregation query to achieve that: ### Modified Aggregation Query ```javascript db.products.aggregate([ { $lookup: { from: "productTemp", localField: "code", foreignField: "code", as: "productTemp" } }, { $unwind: "$productTemp" }, { $match: { "productTemp.code": "310750110" } }, { $project: { code: 1, name: 1, category: 1, "productTemp.description": 1, // Only include description _id: 0 // Exclude the default _id field if not needed } } ]); ``` ### Explanation of the `$project` Stage: - **code: 1**: Include the `code` field from the `products` collection. - **name: 1**: Include the `name` field from the `products` collection. - **category: 1**: Include the `category` field from the `products` collection. - **"productTemp.description": 1**: Include only the `description` field from the `productTemp` array. - **_id: 0**: Exclude the `_id` field from the output if you don't need it. ### Expected Output After running the modified aggregation query, the output would look like this: ```json { "code": "310750110", "name": "Product A", "category": "Electronics", "productTemp": { "description": "A high-quality electronic product" } } ``` This output provides a clean structure with only the relevant information in the `productTemp` field. If there's anything more you'd like to modify or any other questions you have, feel free to ask! üòä

9:18 AM
If you want to modify the aggregation command so that only the `brand` object from the `productTemp` collection is returned in the results, you would need to adjust the final stage of your aggregation pipeline to project only the desired fields. ### Updated MongoDB Aggregation Command Here's how you can do it: ```javascript db.products.aggregate([ { $lookup: { from: "productTemp", localField: "code", foreignField: "code", as: "brandInfo" } }, { $unwind: "$brandInfo" }, { $match: { "brandInfo.brand.name": "Brand A" // You can adjust this to filter as needed } }, { $project: { _id: 0, // Exclude _id from the result if not needed brand: "$brandInfo.brand" // Include only the brand object } } ]); ``` ### Explanation: 1. **$lookup**: Joins `products` with `productTemp` based on the `code` field. 2. **$unwind**: Decomposes the `brandInfo` array into individual documents. 3. **$match**: Filters documents to find those where the `brand`'s name is "Brand A". 4. **$project**: Specifies which fields to include in the output. In this case, we include only the `brand` object and exclude the `_id` field. ### Result With the sample data above, if you run this command, the result will reflect only the brand object: ```json [ { "brand": { "name": "Brand A", "country": "USA" } } ] ``` This output contains just the `brand` object from the `productTemp` collection where the brand name matches "Brand A". Feel free to let me know if you have any further questions or need anything else! üòä

‡πÅ‡∏ô‡πà‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏ô! üòä ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `$unwind` ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô MongoDB aggregation pipeline ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏â‡∏û‡∏≤‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢ ‡πÜ collection ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢ `$lookup` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ array ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå ### ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `$unwind` ‡πÄ‡∏°‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$lookup` ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å collection ‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏û‡∏ö‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏Å‡πá‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏£‡∏π‡∏õ‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á array ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô ‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ collection `employees` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ `departments` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ join ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏´‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏á collection ‡∏™‡∏°‡∏°‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô array ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ä‡∏∏‡∏î‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ú‡∏π‡πâ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏ú‡∏ô‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô **‡∏™‡∏°‡∏°‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å `$lookup`:** ```json { "_id": 1, "name": "Alice", "departmentId": 1, "salary": 70000, "departmentDetails": [ { "_id": 1, "name": "Sales" } ] } ``` ### ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÑ‡∏°‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$unwind`? ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÅ‡∏¢‡∏∞ `departmentDetails` ‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡πÜ ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ñ‡∏±‡∏î‡πÑ‡∏õ ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$match` ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏´‡πå‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á ‡πÜ ‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡∏∏‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$unwind` ### ‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô `$unwind` ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$unwind` ‡πÉ‡∏ô aggregation pipeline: ```javascript { $unwind: "$departmentDetails" } ``` ### ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å `$unwind` ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$unwind` ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÅ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏•‡∏∞ `departmentDetails`: ```json { "_id": 1, "name": "Alice", "departmentId": 1, "salary": 70000, "departmentDetails": { "_id": 1, "name": "Sales" } } ``` ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏ì‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà `departmentDetails` ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô array ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÅ‡∏ú‡∏ô‡∏Å ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô: ```json { "_id": 2, "name": "Bob", "departmentId": 2, "salary": 50000, "departmentDetails": [ { "_id": 2, "name": "HR" }, { "_id": 3, "name": "Finance" } ] } ``` ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$unwind` ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏î‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ: ```json { "_id": 2, "name": "Bob", "departmentId": 2, "salary": 50000, "departmentDetails": { "_id": 2, "name": "HR" } } { "_id": 2, "name": "Bob", "departmentId": 2, "salary": 50000, "departmentDetails": { "_id": 3, "name": "Finance" } } ``` ### ‡∏™‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏õ ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$unwind` ‡πÉ‡∏ô aggregation pipeline ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ó‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÅ‡∏¢‡∏∞ array ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß ‡πÜ ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ß‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏´‡πå‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏™‡∏∞‡∏î‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏¢‡∏¥‡πà‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô ‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏ú‡∏°‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏≠‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô ‡πÜ ‡πÑ‡∏´‡∏°? üòä

8:47 AM
The error message you're seeing indicates that Docker is unable to connect to the Docker daemon (specifically, the `dockerDesktopLinuxEngine`). This can be frustrating, but here are several steps you can take to troubleshoot and resolve this issue: ### 1. **Check if Docker Desktop is Running** - Make sure that Docker Desktop is running. Look for the Docker whale icon in your system tray (usually at the bottom-right of the screen). If it‚Äôs not there, start Docker Desktop. ### 2. **Restart Docker Desktop** - Sometimes, simply restarting Docker Desktop can fix connectivity issues. Right-click the Docker icon in the system tray and select "Quit Docker Desktop," then restart it. ### 3. **Check Docker Settings** - Open Docker Desktop and go to "Settings." Check the following: - **General Settings**: Ensure that "Use the WSL 2 based engine" is enabled if you're looking to run Docker with WSL. - **Resources Tab**: Make sure that the allocated resources (CPU, Memory) are sufficient. - **Reset to Factory Defaults**: As a last resort, you can try resetting Docker to factory settings. This will remove existing containers and images, so use it carefully. ### 4. **Check Windows Services** - Ensure that the Docker-related services are running. You can check this by typing `services.msc` in the Windows Run dialog (Win + R). Look for Docker-related services and make sure they're running. ### 5. **Run Docker from Command Line** - If you are using WSL, try launching your terminal from within WSL and running the command there. This can sometimes bypass issues with the Windows command line. ### 6. **Check Firewall and Antivirus** - Sometimes, firewall or antivirus software can interfere with Docker's network connections. Ensure that Docker is allowed through your firewall and check any security settings in your antivirus software. ### 7. **Reinstall Docker Desktop** - If you've tried all the above and are still facing issues, consider uninstalling Docker Desktop and then reinstalling it from the official website. ### 8. **Check WSL Configuration** - If using WSL, ensure that your WSL version is correct. Open a command prompt and run: ```bash wsl -l -v ``` - Make sure that your distribution is using WSL version 2. If it is not, you can set it using: ```bash wsl --set-version <Distro> 2 ``` Try these steps, and let me know how it goes! I'm here to help! üòä

8:40 AM
To obtain the request IP address of the caller in a C# Web API application when using Nginx as a reverse proxy, you can follow these steps: ### Step 1: Configure Nginx Make sure your Nginx configuration passes the real client IP to your Web API. You can achieve this by adding the following lines to your server block in your Nginx configuration file: ```nginx http { ... # Enable the use of the real IP from the proxy set_real_ip_from 127.0.0.1; # Trust proxy (adjust as necessary) real_ip_header X-Forwarded-For; ... } ``` ### Step 2: Retrieve IP Address in C# Web API In your Web API controller, you can access the caller's IP address through the `HttpContext`. Here‚Äôs an example of how you can do this: ```csharp using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc; [ApiController] [Route("[controller]")] public class MyController : ControllerBase { [HttpGet] public IActionResult Get() { // Get the real IP address of the caller var ipAddress = HttpContext.Connection.RemoteIpAddress.ToString(); // You might also want to check for X-Forwarded-For header if (HttpContext.Request.Headers.ContainsKey("X-Forwarded-For")) { ipAddress = HttpContext.Request.Headers["X-Forwarded-For"].ToString(); } return Ok(new { CallerIp = ipAddress }); } } ``` ### Explanation: 1. **Nginx Configuration**: - `set_real_ip_from` specifies the trusted proxy addresses. Ensure that you adjust this to reflect your actual setup (e.g., if your Nginx server is hosted elsewhere). - The `real_ip_header` instructs Nginx to use the `X-Forwarded-For` HTTP header, which typically contains the client's original IP address. 2. **C# Code**: - You retrieve the remote IP from `HttpContext.Connection.RemoteIpAddress`, which usually gives you the IP address directly. - Additionally, you check for the `X-Forwarded-For` header for cases where multiple proxies might alter the original request. ### Testing Make sure to test your setup by sending requests through Nginx to your Web API and checking if the correct client IPs are logged or returned by your API. This approach should provide you with the caller's IP address accurately in a production environment.

To write test cases for your `Create` and `CreateGroup` methods, we need to consider the following: 1. **Dependencies**: We have dependencies on `_salesOrderService` and `_fiDocumentRepo`, so we'll use mocking to simulate their behavior. 2. **Behavior**: We need to check that the methods handle grouping correctly and that the documents are generated and saved as expected. 3. **Error Handling**: Test for scenarios where there are no sales orders or database exceptions. Below is a sample test case implementation using a framework like NUnit and Moq for your asynchronous methods. ### Setup First, make sure you have NUnit and Moq installed in your test project: ```bash dotnet add package NUnit dotnet add package Moq ``` ### Test Class ```csharp using NUnit.Framework; using Moq; using System.Collections.Generic; using System.Linq; using System.Threading; using System.Threading.Tasks; [TestFixture] public class YourClassTests { private Mock<ISalesOrderService> _mockSalesOrderService; private Mock<IFIDocumentRepo> _mockFiDocumentRepo; private YourClass _yourClass; // Replace with actual class name [SetUp] public void SetUp() { _mockSalesOrderService = new Mock<ISalesOrderService>(); _mockFiDocumentRepo = new Mock<IFIDocumentRepo>(); _yourClass = new YourClass(_mockSalesOrderService.Object, _mockFiDocumentRepo.Object); } [Test] public async Task CreateGroup_WithSalesOrders_CreatesAndStoresDocuments() { // Arrange var salesOrders = new List<SalesOrder> { new SalesOrder { GroupReference = "Group1" }, new SalesOrder { GroupReference = "Group1" }, new SalesOrder { GroupReference = "Group2" } }; _mockSalesOrderService.Setup(s => s.Get(CancellationToken.None)).ReturnsAsync(salesOrders); var generatedDocument = new FiDocument(); // Assuming FiDocument is the response type. _mockFiDocumentRepo.Setup(repo => repo.AddAsync(It.IsAny<FiDocument>(), CancellationToken.None)).Returns(Task.CompletedTask); // Act await _yourClass.Create(); // Assert _mockFiDocumentRepo.Verify(repo => repo.AddAsync(It.IsAny<FiDocument>(), CancellationToken.None), Times.Exactly(2)); // Expecting 2 different groups } [Test] public async Task CreateGroup_WithNoSalesOrders_DoesNotCreateDocuments() { // Arrange var salesOrders = new List<SalesOrder>(); _mockSalesOrderService.Setup(s => s.Get(CancellationToken.None)).ReturnsAsync(salesOrders); // Act await _yourClass.Create(); // Assert _mockFiDocumentRepo.Verify(repo => repo.AddAsync(It.IsAny<FiDocument>(), CancellationToken.None), Times.Never); // No records to process } [Test] public async Task CreateGroup_WhenExceptionThrown_ShouldHandleGracefully() { // Arrange var salesOrders = new List<SalesOrder> { new SalesOrder { GroupReference = "Group1" } }; _mockSalesOrderService.Setup(s => s.Get(CancellationToken.None)).ReturnsAsync(salesOrders); _mockFiDocumentRepo.Setup(repo => repo.AddAsync(It.IsAny<FiDocument>(), CancellationToken.None)).ThrowsAsync(new Exception("Database error")); // Act and Assert Assert.ThrowsAsync<Exception>(async () => await _yourClass.Create()); } } ``` ### Explanation: 1. **Mocks:** We're creating mocks for `ISalesOrderService` and `IFIDocumentRepo` that your class depends on. 2. **Tests:** - The first test, `CreateGroup_WithSalesOrders_CreatesAndStoresDocuments`, verifies that for multiple sales orders with the same group reference, the `AddAsync` method is called for each unique document. - The second test, `CreateGroup_WithNoSalesOrders_DoesNotCreateDocuments`, checks that no document creation is attempted when there are no sales orders. - The third test, `CreateGroup_WhenExceptionThrown_ShouldHandleGracefully`, confirms that the method properly throws an exception if an issue occurs during document creation. ### Considerations: - These tests can be expanded based on specific edge cases or further requirements you encounter in your application. - Adjust the class names and interfaces according to your actual implementation.

‡∏™‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏™‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö! üòä ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$addFields` ‡πÉ‡∏ô MongoDB ‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏õ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏ì‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏∑‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏ô ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ô‡∏ß‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô ‡πÜ ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Å‡πá‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ### ‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏á‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏û‡∏∑‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á `$addFields`: ```json { $addFields: { <newField>: <value>, ... } } ``` ### ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏™‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ì‡πå ‡∏™‡∏°‡∏°‡∏∏‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≠‡∏•‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏Å‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠ `students` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Å‡πá‡∏ö‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ô‡∏±‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ: ```json { "_id": 1, "name": "John", "scores": { "math": 90, "english": 85 } } ``` ‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠ `averageScore` ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ô‡∏ß‡∏ì‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∞‡πÅ‡∏ô‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏±‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ô ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$addFields` ‡∏î‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ: ```json db.students.aggregate([ { $addFields: { averageScore: { $avg: [ "$scores.math", "$scores.english" ] } } } ]) ``` ### ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏î‡∏π‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ: ```json { "_id": 1, "name": "John", "scores": { "math": 90, "english": 85 }, "averageScore": 87.5 } ``` ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$avg` ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ô‡∏ß‡∏ì‡∏Ñ‡∏∞‡πÅ‡∏ô‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏â‡∏•‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå `math` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ `english`. ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô ‡πÜ ‡∏Å‡πá‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö! üòä

4:14 PM
‡πÉ‡∏ô MongoDB, `$unwind` ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏™‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ß‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏• (aggregation operation) ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ "‡πÅ‡∏ï‡∏Å" ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¢‡πå (array) ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£ ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¢‡πå‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÅ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏ß‡∏•‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¢‡πå‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏™‡∏∞‡∏î‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏ì‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏î: ```javascript $unwind: { path: "$matchedDoc", preserveNullAndEmptyArrays: true // Keep documents without a match } ``` ### ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏™‡πà‡∏ß‡∏ô: - `path: "$matchedDoc"`: ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏∏‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¢‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡πÅ‡∏ï‡∏Å‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å (‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠ `matchedDoc`) - `preserveNullAndEmptyArrays: true`: ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡∏π‡πà (match) ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¢‡πå‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á (empty array) ‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏Å‡πá‡∏ö‡πÑ‡∏ß‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏•‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏≠‡∏Å ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏´‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏•‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô ### ‡∏™‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏õ: ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `$unwind` ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏•‡∏±‡∏Å‡∏©‡∏ì‡∏∞‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏î‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¢‡πå‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ü‡∏¥‡∏•‡∏î‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏Å‡πá‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¢‡πå‡πÑ‡∏ß‡πâ ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡πÇ‡∏¢‡∏ä‡∏ô‡πå‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏´‡πå‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏• ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏î‡∏π‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡∏π‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏â‡∏û‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö! üòä
thread_3Qc5YIbGrd9mljxGHaOQUWPo
4:10 PM
To update fields in MongoDB where documents in one collection are missing certain fields present in another collection, you can use the aggregation pipeline combined with the `$merge` stage or perform a simple update using the `$set` operator and a query. Here‚Äôs a general outline for each approach: ### Approach 1: Using Aggregation and `$merge` 1. **Gathering Data**: Use the `$lookup` stage to find corresponding documents from the second collection based on a common field (like the field code). 2. **Filtering Out Missing Fields**: Use `$match` and `$addFields` to find and prepare the documents that lack the specified fields. 3. **Updating the First Collection**: Use `$merge` to write the updates back to the first collection. Here's a sample code to illustrate this: ```javascript db.secondCollection.aggregate([ { $lookup: { from: "firstCollection", localField: "fieldCode", // Change this to your actual field used for matching foreignField: "fieldCode", as: "matchedDoc" } }, { $unwind: { path: "$matchedDoc", preserveNullAndEmptyArrays: true // Keep documents without a match } }, { $match: { "matchedDoc.fieldToUpdate": { $exists: false } // Field that is not present in first collection } }, { $addFields: { "fieldToUpdate": "$valueFromSecondCollection" // Update with values from the second collection } }, { $merge: { into: "firstCollection", whenMatched: [ { $set: { fieldToUpdate: "$fieldToUpdate" // Same field you want to update } } ], whenNotMatched: "discard" // Choose the behavior for unmatched documents if necessary } } ]); ``` ### Approach 2: Using Update with `$set` and `$exists` If you want a simpler approach without aggregation, you can iterate over the second collection and update documents in the first collection. However, this requires scripting (like using Node.js or Python) if you want to automate it: ```javascript const secondDocs = db.secondCollection.find().toArray(); secondDocs.forEach(doc => { db.firstCollection.updateOne( { fieldCode: doc.fieldCode }, // Match condition { $set: { fieldToUpdate: doc.valueToUpdate } }, // Update the field { upsert: false } // No need to insert if not found ); }); ``` ### Adjust Field Names Make sure to replace `fieldCode`, `fieldToUpdate`, and `valueToUpdate` with the actual field names used in your documents. ### Summary - For bulk updating and managing larger datasets efficiently, the first approach with aggregation is often preferable. - For smaller or one-off updates, the second option may be sufficient. Feel free to ask if you need help with specific field names or further MongoDB queries! üòä

‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢ ‡πÜ ‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ô MongoDB ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `field` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤ `code` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤ `field` ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡πÅ‡∏ï‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ ‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏¥‡∏ó‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `bulkWrite` ‡∏ã‡∏∂‡πà‡∏á‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏∏‡∏ç‡∏≤‡∏ï‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡πà‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢ ‡πÜ ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ß ### ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `bulkWrite` ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `bulkWrite` ‡πÉ‡∏ô MongoDB: ```javascript const bulkOps = [ { updateOne: { filter: { code: 'CODE1' }, update: { $set: { fieldToUpdate: 'value1' } } } }, { updateOne: { filter: { code: 'CODE2' }, update: { $set: { fieldToUpdate: 'value2' } } } }, { updateOne: { filter: { code: 'CODE3' }, update: { $set: { fieldToUpdate: 'value3' } } } } // ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πà ]; db.yourCollection.bulkWrite(bulkOps) .then(result => { console.log("Bulk update successful:", result); }) .catch(err => { console.error("Bulk update failed:", err); }); ``` ### ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏î: - `yourCollection`: ‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠ collection ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï - `filter`: ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ñ‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤ `code` ‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ - `update`: ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏∏‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ ### ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ `bulkWrite` - ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏£‡πá‡∏ß: ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏´‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏¢ ‡πÜ ‡πÅ‡∏ñ‡∏ß‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô - ‡∏•‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏¢‡∏∏‡πà‡∏á‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏Å: ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏•‡∏∏‡πà‡∏°‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏ï‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏•‡∏¥‡∏™‡∏ï‡πå ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô ‡πÜ ‡πÅ‡∏à‡πâ‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏∞! üòä

Sure! Here are additional examples of procurement KPIs, segmented by category: ### 1. **Cost Control KPIs** - **Total Spend**: Overall expenditure on procurement over a given period. - **Percentage of Spend under Management**: Proportion of total spend that is actively managed by the procurement department. ### 2. **Supplier Performance KPIs** - **Supplier Scorecard Rating**: A composite score based on various metrics such as quality, delivery, and service. - **Supplier Reliability Index**: A measure of how consistently a supplier meets delivery schedules and quality standards. ### 3. **Process Efficiency KPIs** - **Requisition Cycle Time**: Time taken from the creation of a purchase requisition to approval. - **Purchase Order Accuracy**: Percentage of orders that are fulfilled correctly without discrepancies. ### 4. **Compliance and Risk Management KPIs** - **Audit Compliance Rate**: The percentage of contracts and suppliers that pass audits. - **Supplier Risk Assessment Score**: A risk rating given to suppliers based on financial stability, performance history, and other risk factors. ### 5. **Inventory Management KPIs** - **Days Inventory Outstanding (DIO)**: Average number of days that inventory is held before being sold. - **Carrying Cost of Inventory**: Total cost associated with holding inventory, including storage, depreciation, and opportunity costs. ### 6. **Sustainability and Ethics KPIs** - **Percentage of Sustainable Suppliers**: Proportion of suppliers that meet sustainability criteria. - **Ethical Compliance Rate**: Measure of how well suppliers adhere to ethical standards, like labor practices and environmental regulations. ### 7. **Quality Metrics** - **First-Pass Yield**: Percentage of products received without quality issues on the first inspection. - **Return Rate**: The rate at which goods are returned due to defects or unsatisfactory quality. ### 8. **Strategic Procurement KPIs** - **Procurement ROI**: Return on investment from procurement activities, considering savings and other benefits achieved. - **Value Contribution**: Assessment of how procurement adds value beyond cost savings, including improvements in service and quality. Each of these KPIs provides insights into different aspects of the procurement process and can help organizations make data-driven decisions to enhance efficiency and effectiveness. Do you have any specific segments or KPIs you would like to delve deeper into? üòä

2:38 PM
To get the client's current public IP address in a React application, you can use an external API service that provides the IP address. Here's how to do it step by step: ### Step 1: Choose an API You can use services like `ipify`, `ipapi`, or `ipinfo`. For this example, we'll use `ipify`, which is straightforward and widely used. ### Step 2: Install Axios (optional) If you prefer using Axios for making HTTP requests, you can install it with the following command: ```bash npm install axios ``` ### Step 3: Create a Function to Fetch the IP Address You can create a function in your component to fetch the public IP address. Here is an example using functional components and hooks: ```jsx import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react'; import axios from 'axios'; const PublicIPFetcher = () => { const [ip, setIp] = useState(''); useEffect(() => { const fetchPublicIP = async () => { try { const response = await axios.get('https://api.ipify.org?format=json'); setIp(response.data.ip); } catch (error) { console.error('Error fetching the IP address: ', error); } }; fetchPublicIP(); }, []); return ( <div> <h1>Your Public IP Address</h1> <p>{ip ? ip : 'Loading...'}</p> </div> ); }; export default PublicIPFetcher; ``` ### Explanation: - **useEffect**: This hook runs when the component mounts. It retrieves the public IP address. - **axios.get**: Makes a GET request to `ipify` API, which returns the public IP in JSON format. - **Error Handling**: If there is an error during the fetch, it will log it to the console. - **Conditional Rendering**: It displays "Loading..." until the IP address is fetched. ### Step 4: Use the Component You can use the `PublicIPFetcher` component in your main application or any other components as needed. ### Final Note Since public IP retrieval relies on an external service, ensure you check the service's usage guidelines or rate limits in production environments.
thread_ZWUhf00wRsFdPfZKledALHl8
2:16 PM
Certainly! To update many fields in MongoDB for multiple documents efficiently, you can use the `updateMany` method in combination with bulk operations to ensure better performance. Here are some effective strategies: ### 1. Use Bulk Operations Instead of updating one document at a time, use bulk operations, which can significantly improve performance. Here's an example of how to do that in Node.js using the MongoDB driver: ```javascript const { MongoClient } = require('mongodb'); async function updateManyDocuments(uri, database, collection, updates) { const client = new MongoClient(uri); try { await client.connect(); const db = client.db(database); const coll = db.collection(collection); const bulkOps = updates.map(update => { return { updateOne: { filter: { _id: update._id }, // your filtering condition update: { $set: update.fields } // assuming fields is an object containing the fields to be updated } }; }); const result = await coll.bulkWrite(bulkOps); console.log(`${result.modifiedCount} document(s) updated.`); } catch (error) { console.error('Error updating documents:', error); } finally { await client.close(); } } // Example usage const updates = [ { _id: 1, fields: { field1: 'value1', field2: 'value2' } }, // ... ]; updateManyDocuments('your_mongodb_uri', 'your_database', 'your_collection', updates); ``` ### 2. Use `$set` Wisely When updating many fields, you should structure the `$set` operation efficiently. Instead of multiple update instructions, consolidate fields to minimize the number of updates sent to the server. ### 3. Indexing If you're updating based on specific criteria, ensure you have proper indexes in place. This makes your search/filter operations faster and can improve the overall performance of your updates. ### 4. Use Cursors for Large Batches If you need to update many documents at once, consider fetching them in manageable batches. This can be done using cursors or pagination. Update documents in chunks to avoid overwhelming the server. ### 5. Limit the Number of Fields If possible, limit the number of fields you are updating to what is absolutely necessary. Sometimes updating only the required fields leads to better performance. ### 6. Monitor and Optimize Regularly monitor the performance of your MongoDB server. You can use tools like MongoDB Atlas or OpsManager to get insights into query performance and slow operations. ### Example of Bulk Update with Filters Here is an example that demonstrates updating multiple fields for documents matching a given filter: ```javascript const updates = [ { _id: 1, fields: { field1: 'newValue1', field2: 'newValue2' } }, { _id: 2, fields: { field3: 'newValue3', field4: 'newValue4' } }, // Add more updates here ]; // Update statements map const bulkOps = updates.map(update => ({ updateOne: { filter: { _id: update._id }, update: { $set: update.fields } } })); await collection.bulkWrite(bulkOps); ``` ### Conclusion By applying these strategies, you should be able to update many fields in MongoDB more efficiently. If you have specific requirements or need more tailored advice, feel free to ask! üòä

2:05 PM
The error "**Property deploy_dev is not allowed.yaml-schema: Deployer Recipe**" indicates that the property `deploy_dev` is not recognized or permissible according to the defined YAML schema for the Deployer Recipe you are using. This typically happens when the YAML structure is incorrect or if you're using property names that are not defined in the schema. ### Example Scenario of the Error Let's say you have a YAML configuration like this: ```yaml deploy_dev: stage: deploy variables: UPSTREAM_ENVIRONMENT_STAGE: dev UPSTREAM_ENVIRONMENT_IMAGE_TAG: $IMAGE_REGISTRY trigger: project: some/project branch: main ``` In this case, if the schema for your Deployer Recipe does not support `deploy_dev` as a top-level property, you will encounter the error mentioned. ### Causes of the Error 1. **Property Not Defined in Schema**: The `deploy_dev` property might not be included in the expected semantics of the pipeline's schema. 2. **Incorrect Structure**: The structure of your YAML file might not align with the hierarchy expected by the schema. ### How to Fix the Error 1. **Check the Schema Documentation**: Refer to the specific schema documentation for the Deployer Recipe you are implementing. Ensure that you are using the correct properties and that `deploy_dev` is a valid key. 2. **Review the Structure**: Adjust the structure to align with the expected format. Here‚Äôs an example of how the corrected structure might look: ```yaml deployer: version: 1 jobs: deploy_dev: stage: deploy variables: UPSTREAM_ENVIRONMENT_STAGE: dev UPSTREAM_ENVIRONMENT_IMAGE_TAG: $IMAGE_REGISTRY trigger: project: some/project branch: main ``` ### Example of a Valid Configuration Here‚Äôs an example of a valid configuration based on proper structure and schema compliance: ```yaml deployer: version: 1 jobs: deploy: stage: deploy variables: UPSTREAM_ENVIRONMENT_STAGE: dev UPSTREAM_ENVIRONMENT_IMAGE_TAG: $IMAGE_REGISTRY trigger: project: some/project branch: main rules: - if: '$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == "main"' ``` ### Key Points to Ensure - Make sure to define the `deploy_dev` under the correct parent key, such as `jobs` or `steps`, as required by the schema. - Validate your YAML file with a linter or validator to catch any structural issues. - Run your CI/CD pipeline again after making the necessary adjustments. By following these guidelines, you should be able to resolve the error and successfully deploy your recipe. If you need further help or examples, feel free to ask! üòä

**‡πÄ‡∏™‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á**: Kustomize ‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏û‡∏ö‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡πÄ‡∏ô‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏™‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏∏‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏´‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏á - **‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏ú‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏û‡∏•‡∏≤‡∏î‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå YAML**: ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏û‡∏ö‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏ä‡∏µ‡πâ '-'. ‡∏ô‡∏±‡πà‡∏ô‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ü‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡πÅ‡∏°‡∏ï YAML ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏±‡∏î‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà 14 ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏à‡∏∞‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á ‡πÄ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ô ‡∏Ç‡∏≤‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏¢ '-' ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÅ‡∏™‡∏î‡∏á‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏•‡∏¥‡∏™‡∏ï‡πå„ÄÇ ### ‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏Å‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏Ç 1. **‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏™‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏≤‡∏á**: ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏™‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏∏‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå base ‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå `deployment.yml` ‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏á ‡πÜ 2. **‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå YAML**: ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏¥‡∏î‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå `deployment.yml` ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏±‡∏î‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà 14 ‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏™‡∏î‡∏á‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ü‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡πÅ‡∏°‡∏ï YAML ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á: ```yaml ## ‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á - name: example image: my-image:v1 ``` 3. **‡∏ó‡∏î‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Kustomize**: ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏á‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÅ‡∏Å‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå YAML ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏™‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏•‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á Kustomize ‡∏≠‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏´‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏Å‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏°‡∏∏‡∏°‡∏°‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô YAML ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ Kustomize ‡πÅ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏∞! üòä

contains an array to hold multiple customer entries. 2. **Individual Customer Entries**: - The first entry is for **"‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏õ‡∏ß‡∏µ‡∏ì‡∏≤ ‡∏≠‡∏∏‡∏ó‡∏±‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏í‡∏ô‡πå"**, including both billing and work addresses. - The second entry captures the change from **old customer** to **new customer**, maintaining their respective details. - The third entry includes a customer who buys from someone else, with their business unit and details. ### Benefits of this structure: - **Clarity**: Related information is grouped under the respective customer, making it easier to read and understand. - **Scalability**: You can easily add more customers or further details without complicating the structure. - **Accessibility**: Each piece of information is easily retrievable through clear property names. thread_J26vnhbPkU1JnZwuCdHc5cL8
11:28 AM
The error message you're seeing indicates a problem with the command syntax when trying to publish your .NET project. Specifically, the error is: - **MSBUILD : error MSB1008: Only one project can be specified.**: This means that the command has incorrectly specified the project file or the options. ### What Went Wrong: The issue appears to be with the command you are using to publish your project. Specifically, there is a missing space between the project file path and the `-c Release` option. It reads as a single argument instead of treating the project file and the options separately. ### Correct Command Syntax: You should ensure that there is a space between the project file and the `-c` flag. The corrected command should look like this: ```bash dotnet publish "SapInterfaceJob/SapInterfaceJob.csproj" -c Release -o /app/publish ``` ### Breakdown of Changes: - **"SapInterfaceJob/SapInterfaceJob.csproj"**: This part correctly specifies the path to the project file. - **`-c Release`**: Ensure there is a space before the `-c` option, which specifies the build configuration as "Release." ### Updated Dockerfile Example: If you are using this in a Dockerfile, make sure the command looks like this: ```dockerfile RUN dotnet publish "SapInterfaceJob/SapInterfaceJob.csproj" -c Release -o /app/publish ``` ### Final Steps: After making the above correction, try rebuilding your Docker image. This should resolve the issue and allow the publish command to execute successfully. If you encounter more errors, feel free to share them! üòä
thread_cZXi7fMBDb3SdrJa7D2Vf8QA
11:03 AM
‡πÅ‡∏ô‡πà‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏ô! ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏á CronJob ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô Manual Run ‡πÉ‡∏ô Argo Workflows ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏õ‡∏Å‡∏ï‡∏¥‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Workflow ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Argo ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Job ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Workflow ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô CronJob ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏ö‡∏ô‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô Argo: ```yaml apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1 kind: Workflow metadata: generateName: loadtest-sap- spec: entrypoint: loadtest-sap-job templates: - name: loadtest-sap-job script: image: registryii.thaibevapp.com/otcsell/sap/loadtest-sap/dev/backend command: ["sh", "-c"] source: | echo "Running load test..." # ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏™‡πà‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πà ``` ### ‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô 1. **‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î Workflow**: ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå YAML ‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏°‡πà‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö Argo Workflow ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏á‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏î‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏ö‡∏ô 2. **‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£**: ‡πÉ‡∏™‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ Container ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏ß‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô `source:` 3. **‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô Workflow**: ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏ô Workflow ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö Manual ‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô Argo UI ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á CLI ### ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á Workflow 1. ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Workflow ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏¢‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á kubectl: ```bash kubectl create -f your-workflow-file.yaml ``` 2. ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏à‡∏™‡∏≠‡∏ö‡∏™‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô Argo UI ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á: ```bash argo get @latest ``` ### ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏ï‡∏∏ - ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö `script` ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏™‡∏¥‡πà‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ Container ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô - ‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤ Image ‡πÉ‡∏ô Workflow ‡∏≠‡∏≤‡∏à‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å Registry ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì ‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏á Workflow ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ô‡∏∞‡∏Ñ‡∏∞! üòä

‡πÉ‡∏ô **Argo Workflows** ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô **CronJob** ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ **Job** ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏Å‡∏î‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Argo Workflows ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ Workflow ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô Job ‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏ú‡∏π‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ: ### 1. ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Workflow Definition ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå YAML ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î Workflow ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Argo ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏∏‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Job ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô: ```yaml apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1 kind: Workflow metadata: generateName: loadtest-sap-workflow- spec: entrypoint: loadtest-sap templates: - name: loadtest-sap container: image: registryii.thaibevapp.com/otcsell/sap/loadtest-sap/dev/backend resources: requests: memory: "100Mi" cpu: "100m" limits: memory: "200Mi" cpu: "200m" ``` ### 2. ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô Workflow ‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô Argo UI 1. **‡πÇ‡∏õ‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏°‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á Argo UI**: ‡∏Å‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏∑‡πà‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÅ‡∏ô‡πà‡πÉ‡∏à‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤ Argo CLI ‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞ Argo Workflows Controller - ‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÇ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏î Workflow YAML ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á Argo: ```bash argo submit loadtest-sap-workflow.yaml --watch ``` 2. **‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á Argo UI**: ‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ò‡∏µ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á Argo UI ‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡πà‡∏≤‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á Kubernetes Cluster ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì - ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏™‡∏±‡πà‡∏á `kubectl port-forward` ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á Argo UI: ```bash kubectl port-forward svc/argo-server -n argo 2746:2746 ``` - ‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏¥‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏ß‡πá‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏ß‡πå‡πÄ‡∏ã‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà `http://localhost:2746` 3. **‡∏Å‡∏î‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô Workflow**: ‡∏ö‡∏ô Argo UI: - ‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏¥‡∏Å‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà "Submit New Workflow" - ‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÇ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏î‡πÑ‡∏ü‡∏•‡πå YAML ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏∂‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà 1 ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡πÉ‡∏ô UI ‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á - ‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Å "Submit" ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô Workflow ### 3. ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô‡πÉ‡∏ô CronJob ‡∏ñ‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ **CronJob** ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÅ‡∏°‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏ß‡∏•‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î: - ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Å‡∏î‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô Workflow ‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏Å Argo UI ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ö‡πà‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ ### 4. ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ Outputs ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏á Workflow ‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö Outputs ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ Logs ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ú‡∏•‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ ### ‡∏™‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏õ ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ Argo Workflows ‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô Container ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠ Job ‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà CronJob ‡∏à‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏ó‡∏≥‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô Kubernetes ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏Å‡∏î‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á Workflow ‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏£‡∏π‡∏õ‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏ï‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£ ‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏õ‡πÇ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏î‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ú‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ô Argo UI ‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏Å‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ñ‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô Argo Workflows ‡∏´‡∏£‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏â‡∏û‡∏≤‡∏∞‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏à‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏° ‡∏¢‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏µ‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ä‡πà‡∏ß‡∏¢‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö! üòä
